description:
Great place with excellent oysters, and I highly recommend sitting at the bar. 

6stars if possible
author: Sky L.

description:
Oh my. This place is amazing from top to bottom.

We made a last minute reservation for my birthday on a Monday evening. Coming back from a day in Point Reyes, I had oysters on my mind and we were running late. A quick call to the restaurant regarding our delay and it was not a problem that we were running 10 minutes behind schedule.

Location: Located in FiDi, I can see this place having a pretty happening happy hour. I kind of wished we were back in the city early enough for it, but oh well. 

Ambiance: Walking in, it's dimly lit, but the tropical wallpaper keeps the place looking modern and fresh. The seating is limited and it as pretty packed when we walked in - glad we made that reservation! I can see why this place won Best Designed New Restaurant by Bon Appetit (as well as being a James Beard nominee)! Both great for a classy happy hour or a romantic date night.

Service: Excellent service! Very friendly and attentive.

Drinks: I didn't have any expectations regarding the cocktails, but after reading captions for pictures of the Garden Party and being a gin lover, I had to order it. Probably one of top three favorite cocktails ever. Delicious. You could taste the gin, but the herbs, jardesca, and egg whites just complemented each other really well and it went down smoothly. There are few cocktails I ever crave, but I can see this being one of them. The second cocktail I had was the Barbarita which was also nice and refreshing, but the Garden Party was hands down my favorite.

Food: We came mainly for the oysters so we basically just went down the list and tried at least one of everything for the plain raw oysters. There were a couple that we ordered doubles. We also tried the uni topped oysters which were divine. They were served with a couple sauces, but honestly, they all tasted better plain. There was one type that was rather salty and the sauce helped cut the salt. In terms of hot food, we ordered the crab and artichoke dip served with potato chips and the octopus. Both were delicious. The dip had nice chunks of crab and wasn't overly creamy. The octopus was perfectly cooked and not chewy at all. For dessert, my date and I split the lemon mousse with brown butter streusel and strawberries. It was just the right amount of sweetness without being too much at the end of the meal.

Price: This place definitely isn't cheap, but they have a great happy hour deal that could save you some dough. It's worth it for special occasions, though.

Would I return? Anytime!
author: Leana L.

description:
Vintage Mermaid Everything.

This place is gorgeous inside. Dreamy lights, tropical wallpaper, and antique-styled glassware. Prices are a bit high, but it's worth it since the service, space, and food/drinks are bomb. 

Oysters are $1.50 during happy hour and you can get a delicious Rose for $10 as well. The perfect romantic spot to impress someone or even to just chill and feel fancy.
author: Patty B.

description:
For the price, I expected Leo's to be a better experience overall, but I walked away questioning whether I'd want to come here again for food or just nice photos.

As everyone else has said, this place is absolutely photo worthy. It's beautiful inside and out, particularly the front of the house with the natural light.

We arrived on a Monday evening at 5:00 pm. A waiter walked up to the hostess desk and looked and sounded about as interested in helping as he would be watching paint dry. When I asked for a table for two, his reply was, "We're currently only serving from the Happy Hour menu, you ARE aware of that, right?" I knew very little about Leo's before showing up so, no, I didn't know we'd arrived at the tail end of Happy Hour, but I figured we could order a drink and wait a half an hour before ordering from the dinner menu, which we did. Not sure why the attitude was necessary. We were seated in the corner table, to the right of the entry.

Our waitress was bizarre. She was nice, but with a discernible air of judginess. I ordered the Bubble Bath cocktail ($14), but when my boyfriend tried to order the IPA and was told it was sold out (and had been since Saturday), he decided to go with water instead and her disapproval was noticeable. She perked up a bit when he decided to go with the Station J cocktail ($14), but as the night went on she seemed increasingly less enthusiastic about serving us. She was also a little pushy about trying to get us to order more drinks when we weren't even done with the ones we had.

It took about 20 minutes for our Happy Hour order of two Little Leo oysters to come to the table ($1.50 each), despite the restaurant not being busy. My boyfriend at least enjoyed the oysters and thought they were very fresh.

Just after 5:30 (and the end of Happy Hour), we ordered the fries with dynamite sauce ($7), tea leaf salad ($15), and the raviolo ($21). Service got slower from this point on; a huge Salesforce party was being held in the back room, which was straining the servers. The fries and salad came out first. The fries were incredibly good, super hot and crispy, with a spicy dipping sauce that had tiny roe mixed in. Interesting, but the fishy flavor wasn't exactly what I wanted out of that sauce. The tea leaf salad was fine, but definitely underwhelming. If you're looking for a tea leaf salad to rival Burma Superstar's, this isn't it. It was lacking that punch of complex flavors I'm accustomed to.

We saved a portion of the salad to eat with the ravioli, but we didn't know our waitress was waiting for us to finish the salad before bringing the entree. It took a half an hour of sitting with half a plate of salad in front of us for her to come around and confusedly ask if we were done with it. We said we were still working on it, which really threw her off, and she said she hadn't brought the ravioli because our small table wouldn't fit both plates.

...What?

She asked if we were ok with putting the salad plate on the ledge on the wall we were seated against and we of course had no problem with that. Her hesitancy seemed even more comical when she brought the ravioli and we comfortably fit both plates of food and our serving dishes on the tabletop. Why she took so long to approach us when she'd apparently seen we'd been sitting waiting for the ravioli for so long, I don't know, but I've never had a waiter not bring out food because they thought the table was too small to fit the plates, or wait 30 minutes to express such a minor concern.

Regardless, the ravioli was stunningly plated and looked like a springtime painting, covered in edible flowers. The ravioli were unusual in construction; they were large, flat sheets of pasta filled with ricotta in a brown butter sauce and folded over to house the cheese, rather than the stuffed pasta one might associate with ravioli. The flavors were light and delicate and the heirloom tomatoes were juicy and bright.

We finished the meal with a pineapple sundae ($7), consisting of vanilla ice cream, candied pineapple, pistachios, and caramel. I thought the sundae was just the right amount of sweet without being nauseating. Perfect size for sharing, and definitely enough for one person without feeling overly stuffed by the end of the meal.

Total before the tip was $93.00. The only dish that really blew me away was the ravioli, for its presentation, flavors, and portion size; while the sundae was great and the fries were tasty, it's not like spending an arm and a leg at Leo's is the only way to get a good sundae or some decent fries in the Bay Area. It feels like you're paying more for the experience and the bragging rights of saying you've dined at one of the most Instagramable locations in San Francisco. And the slow, strange service isn't exactly a lure to come back.

But there are a handful of things on the menu I'm still curious about, so I'd be willing to give Leo's one more chance to impress me with the food, rather than the decor.
author: Angela M.

description:
Had to make a stop for the oysters!  And happy that we did.  We ordered a west coast variety and they were some of the best oysters I have ever had.  Sweet, succulent, plump little morsels of oyster heaven.  Shucking is an art form that Leo's definitely has down.  The presentation is spot on and I love the decor of the entire place.  Photo-worthy, for sure.

It's an upscale location so be prepared to pay a little bit extra.  I felt like I was living my best life and would happily visit again, our waiter was so friendly and made us feel at home.
author: Lindsey P.

description:
Came for the happy hour but just missed it at 5:30.   Still had a bottle of wine and oysters.   The oysters are quite expensive when not in happy hour so don't do this often.  

Note that the front of the restaurant and bar can be really loud.   If you make it to the way back it's a bit quieter.  They also have a party room which is good to know.  

Besides the raw oysters also had grilled octopus which was very nice.   Add a delicious lobster roll and was quite full.  Delicious.   The lobster roll came with chips not fries like some pictures show.  We did get fries on the side though and they were fresh and hot.
author: Marcus K.

description:
When Leo's first opened, the food was spectacular.  I went often on my own dime, but frequently suggested it for business lunches given the higher prices.  My last couple of visits, however, were disappointing.

I have a tendency to stick with the same order if I enjoyed it the first time, so it wasn't until recently after I confirmed a shellfish allergy (Yes, I am heartbroken.) that I ordered entrees other than the lobster roll with skinny fries (and the Leo's deviled egg).

Clearly, Leo's is a seafood restaurant, so I guess it shouldn't have come as a complete surprise that the disappointing items were all non-seafood.  For example, the crostini of the beef tartare was rock hard (almost inedible, but worry not, this carboholic powered through and ate most of it anyway).  Now that I can no longer enjoy seafood, I probably won't come to Leo's again.  But, if you decide to go, stick to what they should be good at . . . seafood; and prepare to pay a lot for it.
author: Christina L.

description:
It had been a while since I didn't leave a new spot I checked out disappointed, so I give extra thanks to Leo's. 

This is an oyster bar, so, naturally, we opted for alcohol and oysters. Cool concept drinks, and some of the freshest oysters I've had locally. 

On my list as a go-to.
author: Paulina F.

description:
Get that camera phone ready, this place is all sorts of photoworthy! I've been lusting over Leo's Oyster Bar for about a year now and finally made it in for some fresh oysters and cocktails. I made a reservation for 5:45 pm on a Saturday and while I'm glad our spot was held, we probably would've been just fine without it. The host led us to a secret-feeling back room that's just as fun and kitschy as the front, just sans natural light. Upon sitting down we took a look at both the food and drink menus. I'll note that if you're not into seafood, there are really only a couple things you can eat here (even the deviled eggs has some sort of seafood in them). 

We ordered a round of drinks and a half dozen oysters--oysters are definitely on the pricy side, but really good. We tried two of the Grassy Bars from CA, two of the Drake's Bays from CA, one of the Irish Points from PEI, and one Saquish from MA. Love that they serve them with mignonette and green chile--I've never had green chile on oysters before, but I'm a fan.

The drinks were yummy, although a tad sweet and not very booze forward. I ordered the Garden Party to start--if you're into pretty cocktails, this is one to order. We were there celebrating my birthday and our very nice server suggested a tequila popsicle cocktail. This drink was as refreshing as it was fun and was honestly more boozy than the first one--not sure what it's called, but I would suggest trying it. I will say that my friend had their spin on a spicy marg and the last sip was so spicy that she was in pain for a little while.

All in all, I think this is a lovely spot to start your evening for some pretty vibes and not-super-boozy cocktails. This neighborhood, like most in SF, is very walkable for a post-HH dinner in the Financial District, Chinatown, or Union Square.
author: Megan R.

description:
This place is definitely bougie, with an island hipster twist. I LOVE the decor of this place.


For appetizers, we ordered tater tots and leo's deviled egg. Five dollars for one deviled egg is pricey, but it was SO worth it. The oyster on top with some kind of buffalo sauce, really put a new twist on the deviled egg. The tater tots definitely weren't what I expected, but they had good flavor.

As an entree, I got the lobster roll which was good, but I don't think it was worth $35. I've had bigger, meatier rolls for about $20 at other places.


I'll most likely be back to try out their dinner menu.
author: Khrystine C.

description:
I really wanted to like this place and was looking forward to eating here and taking pictures (totally Instagram worthy). I was able to score reservation on Friday night and was seated in the middle room that had palm leaf wallpaper. I believe there's three rooms as I saw other guest going to another back room. 

Our server was kind and we were quickly given our menus and asked if we wanted sparkling or still water. You were also given a menu for the days oyster picks. Our waiter was kind enough to describe each oyster and where it was from. Each oyster cost about 4 to 6 dollars each. They also had a great selection of cocktails and I highly recommend the garden party. It was refreshing and delicious. 

Upon looking at the menu we decided we were going to have an array of appetizers along with oysters. We ordered the french fries the shishito peppers, tater tots, butterfish confit and half a dozen oysters. The highlight of my night was the oysters and unfortunately everything else was "okay." We also never got out shishito peppers but our waiter apologized and I was feeling very underwhelmed by the rest of our dinner. 

Aside from great photo ops I would only comeback for happy hour. I hear the oysters are $1 and the drinks were tasty!
author: Chantal Noelle T.

description:
The restaurant is beautiful, the staff is friendly, and the food is delicious. 

Sit near the Raw Bar if possible, it's fascinating to watch them shuck the oysters. Each one is carefully checked and beautifully displayed. 

The attention to detail is amazing, from the plating to the decor.
author: Tara D.

description: Service was outstanding, attentive and thoughtful. We ordered a couple of every oyster and they were all fresh and nicely presented. French fries were also good and paired surprisingly well with the oysters. Treat yourself to a unique experience in the beautifully designed space by Ken Fulk.
author: Rad A.

description: Had an amazing dinner! Ok server was Rob and he took great care of us. Explained the menu and helped decide our dinner. The lobster roll is out of this world. Great service. Great food. Great vibe. Will be back soon!
author: Brandon G.

description:
Came into Leo's Oyster Bar on a slight whim. The day was overcast and we were instantly transported to a tropical oasis. The decor is so fun!

We sat at the bar, ordered some drinks and a lot of oysters. (What else would you do at an oyster bar?!) 

While it was slightly pricey, the quality was great and I would definitely recommend this spot for a few drinks and oysters.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
This place was a bit fancier than I expected.  I really like the hip, palm leaves decor and hipster vibe.  I ignored the three $$$, but after getting the bill, that was completely accurate, especially with drinks.  It was worth every penny.

DINNER
Oysters- my favorite are Little Leo
Mushroom toast
Bone marrow
Tuna dip
Lobster roll
Fries
Tater tots

All the food was really delicious, the service was amazing, and I have no complaints.  I highly recommend getting a reservation, we did walk in and had to wait a while.
author: Lyn C.

description:
I had long dreamed of having a seafood tower at Leo's, and talked it up to my friends. We finally went after work one Thursday, and were sort of disappointed. It's not a set tower/plateau as I am used to. This can be good if you like controlling what you get, but the presentation was lacking and I felt like it wasn't worth the price. Bafflingly too, for an oyster bar, the staff are either not knowledgeable or coordinated. My friends described flavor profiles and what they enjoy in oysters, and got wildly conflicting recommendations. 

I would skip the "composed" oysters, unless you're okay paying an extra dollar for a small shaving of melon or veggies, or extra $3 - $5 for an even smaller amount of uni or caviar. I am especially bitter that the cocktail shrimp was $4 per shrimp, and ONE crab leg was $14. Two lobster claws were equally painful at $26 per order. I am not a cheap person. I will pay a good amount for things that are worth it: anything rare or unusual, or perfectly executed. I understand raw seafood has its price, but I have never felt as badly bilked as I did with Leo's raw menu.

I also felt the servers were very pushy in trying to get us to order more, to the point where I was getting annoyed. We made it clear that we were there to have the seafood plateau - which we had already spent a good amount on - would order something from the cooked menu once the kitchen opened at 5 pm, and were happy with our drinks. At first I thought they were being attentive by coming over to refill our waters or freshen our napkins, but it soon became clear it was always to ask if we would order more. It's a shame, because the ambiance could be great for a date night or special occasion with friends (this was our reunion after over a year of not seeing each other, so I really didn't appreciate all the interruptions). I would like to give them another shot, because the dinner menu sounds incredible and like it could be worth the pricing.
author: Cat N.

description:
My first time ever trying oysters(and my first yelp review!) and I couldn't be happier that it was at Leo's! Gui(or however you spell it, pronounced "ghee") was incredible at helping my party pick and choose which ones to try. I went with some oyster loving folks and they really enjoyed it as well. Cocktails were wonderfully made. The prices are sliightly higher than just your average joint, but you are paying for the atmosphere, ambiance, and service. Well worth it! 

LOVED the interior design. Tip: if you want to snap some good pics, get there right at opening!
author: Katya F.

description:
As I was walking in the restaurant, My heart dropped and I fell in love. The interior is just breath taking. 

My friend and I got to sit at the bar, near the oyster station. We got to see the whole restaurant from where I was sitting and I love it. Services was great. Everyone was helpful and knowledgeable because I had a lot of questions. 

Started with cocktails. **Garden Party (GIN, jardesca, egg whites and fresh herbs) It tasted great and super pretty too. From the raw bar, we got half dozen of **Fresh Oysters. They are pricey, around $4 per oyster but they are so sweet and fresh. Wish we got more. Also go some **Baked Oysters (UNI butter baked oysters, ahi tuna and lime) as well because I saw uni and I couldn't resist. They were so good, not overly salted which was great!  **Foie Gras Toast, each bite was full of flavor. They use uni butter too, scream OMG. 

Large entrees I got to try the **Steam Clams. The sake booth was perfect. It's made with octopus, who does that? So delicious! My friend got the **Braised ShortRibs. Very tender but if I'm at Leos, get the seafood. Can't wait to come back.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Things really add up quick here so if you're not expecting to shell out $80 bucks per person for a nice dinner then you might want to rethink your casual dinner option. But, for a special occasion this place is great, beautiful ambiance, friendly service, water constantly being refilled without asking, exchanging plates consistently, amazing cocktails. This is a Treat Yo Self kinda place.

I came here with my boyfriend to celebrate my birthday. I read on yelp that people could make a reservation and get happy hour. 

When I asked if we could order from the happy hour menu the waitress said they don't do HH. Disappointed! I'm guessing HH is only at the bar, but she so definitively said they don't offer HH that it was confusing.
author: Candice C.

description:
3.5 stars.  Came for dinner with my boyfriend tonight.  Everyone was super friendly and attentive.

I had called ahead to see if we could move our reservation up and they said they had availability but in the front area.

I actually didn't realize that the restaurant was so big!

When we arrived, we had a nice corner table facing the entrance.

The menu looked great.  Lots of different choices and I was a bit leary leaning towards the meat but the short rib dish was calling my name.

Our waitress recommended the lobster roll and the salmon.  However, we decided to go with the Hamachi and ribs.

To start the tea leaf salad... It was ok, honestly felt like I've had better at more low end restaurants so was a tiny bit underwhelmed.

The Hamachi was simple but probably my favorite dish.  I love me some avocado ha!

The ribs were good but portion was definitely a bit on the smaller side. 

Overall loved the ambiance and the service but the food wasn't spectacular.  Maybe I'll try the lobster roll and give more love though.
author: Kimberly L.

description: Most romantic cute date restaurant! Loved the decor. Kind of loud but amazing food and drinks
author: Lillian J.

description:
Atmosphere:  5 Stars. Love the bold floral wall paper, the amber toned lights and gold accented furniture. This place is really beautiful and is great for date night or girls night. Would definitely just come back for the chic atmosphere. 

Food:  3 Stars. For 3 people we got 3 raw oysters, 3 cooked oysters ( two uni butter and one deviled egg) Japanese hamachi, foie gras toast, bone marrow. For dessert we got the pineapple sundae and the apple crisp. The bone marrow and foie toast was really good.  The uni butter on the foie toast gave it a smooth decadent flavor. The raw oyster was super small!  Like the size of a clam but it has great flavor. The cooked oysters were not good. They tasted very oceany so I will just stick to raw next time. The hamachi was ok. It was a little salty and tart. Nothing too special about the fish.  

The desserts were good but again unfortunately nothing really special. The ice cream was in fact a let down for me. A little too icy. 

Value:  2 Stars- overpriced.  The portions are incredibly small and the menu is very overpriced. All three of us came not that hungry and left not that full. If you're looking for a satisfying meal be sure to bring the $$$$. 

So overall this is a three star place but I bumped it up to four because I honestly would come back here for the beautiful space and atmosphere. It was a really fun night and if you have the money or don't mind spending it, why not?
author: Suzanne W.

description:
Super cool space...but i wouldn't expect anything less from designer Ken Fulk.  I love the glam feminine touch everywhere!  

The food itself is good but slightly pricey.  The oysters and clams are fresh, the baked oysters were delicious.  Bone marrow with uni was on the smaller side.  The deviled eggs were tasty but expensive at $6 a pop. I enjoyed my Lobster Roll as it was filled with large chunk of lobster meat on a buttered bun.  I was able to order a side of ahi tuna instead of getting it with the salad.  Besides the Lobster Roll, the other highlight for me was the Bloody Mary drink- it was spicy and perfect!  One sip woke me up!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Picked Leo's Oyster Bar for my last hurrah in SF....BAD idea. 
Ambiance and decor is great. 
Amazed at the variety of oysters - so we got all of them!
At the time, they tasted great.
Two hours later...I'm sick to my stomach and vomiting up my $$$ meal.
author: Hieu H.

description:
Mostly incredible food, fun/tropical decor, awesome staff.

This was almost a 5-star review. It came SOOO close. There were a couple things I had that I didn't love, but damn, this was one of the better meals I've had this year!

The hits:

Caviar bite with caviar, creme fraiche, and truffled beet pancake - HOLY HELL THIS BITE IS FANTASTIC. It's literally a bite, but wow... I could have eaten these all night long and nothing else. The perfect balance of salty, sweet, and creamy. The beet isn't overwhelming at all (I'm not a huge beet person), nor is the truffle. The tiny little chives and crystals of salt on top are just enough garnish to feel fancy without being pretentious, and the little pancake is a pillowy puff of goodness below a brief taste of ocean. I can't with this. So. Good.

Lobster roll with uni butter, brioche, and french fries - this is the best lobster roll I've had in SF. Not ever, but definitely in SF. There was literally nothing in it other than lobster and butter, which is how it should be. Nothing to get in the way... the lobster was fresh, tender, and flavorful. The fries were crispy, topped with flakes of parsley, and served with a side of aioli. This dish truly let the lobster shine and I enjoyed every bite.

Smoked tuna dip with roe and togarashi crackers - all the pieces here were fantastic. The crackers were super crunchy and a little spicy. OMG to the smoke on the dip. It's like eating wood out of the smoker, in the absolute best way. The texture of the cracker paired well with the softer quality of the dip and the roe on top was a nice touch. I wouldn't have minded more of it.

The others:

Japanese hamachi with charred avocado and sea salt - the fish was super fresh. The hamachi itself was perfect and I liked the earthy flavors brought in from the olive oil. The rest of the dish was kinda just ok though... the avocado was nicely charred, but it was also slightly brown and not quite ripe. The dish also didn't need the extra salt.

Caviar bite with salmon roe, salmon tartare and capers - this one was much fishier than the first caviar bite we had. I was ok with it, though it was a turn off for my friend. Between the salmon and the capers this was also a very salty bite, though it was slightly balanced out by the dill. It was served in a little mini pie crust... the first bite was good for me, but as I got to the crust a mustard-type flavor kicked in and between that and the thick breading, I lost the fish flavors I was enjoying.

Caviar bite with trout roe and broiled trout - slightly gingery, slightly smoky, a bit of soy, crispy broiled trout. I liked this bite, though not as much as the first.

Overall, I loved Leo's and I'd definitely come back. While pricy and small portioned, I thought the quality and freshness of the fish largely justified the prices and our server was beyond excellent.
author: Samantha B.

description: The oysters here were delicious as were the two different soups, bisque and clam chowder. Service was prompt and professional and I loved the design of the space. The great surprise was the amazing desert for $5, the chocolate mousse!
author: Andrea Y.

description:
I have come here twice - once for lunch and once for drinks & dessert. Absolutely loved both times. 

For lunch, what I loved were the oysters, salad, and pineapple sundae. I also tried the shrimp and salmon burger. The shrimp was good, but standard. The salmon burger was lovely, but I think I would like to try a different entree next time. 

For drinks & dessert, I loved the lucky tanuki, station J, and lemon mousse brown sugar streusel strawberry. The garden party was just okay for me, but maybe it's because I like my cocktails less concentrated in alcohol :). 

The servers are extremely knowledgeable and very kind. I highly recommend this place for its food/drinks, service, and interior decor!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Wow! This place was great. Our sever Rob was of great help, and made us feel like we were regulars. The food and ambiance along with a great sever makes for a 5 star experience, and the oysters, lobster roll, and the must try deviled eggs with fried oysters on top all lived up to their hype. We will be back again next summer, thanks!
author: Patrick R.

description:
The good: Beautiful decor and the bar looks great. Excellent foie gras toast and specialty oysters (we ordered the fancy oysters and the one with the uni on top). We especially appreciated the chef coming out to apologize to us for the wait on the oysters and gave us two complimentary ones. 

The not so good: The other food that we got, the smoked tuna dip (okay) and clam chowder (good), came out pretty late and out of the order that our waiter mentioned it would be in. Service overall was alright considering that the restaurant was full while we were dining. I would have given this place 4 stars, but docked off one because we paid with large bills and waited to get change back. However, a few minutes later we saw our waiter pocketing the change that we were expecting back at the cash drawer. We had planned on tipping fairly close to the amount that was taken, but I believe that it's just common courtesy to not assume that we didn't need change back or at least ask if we needed the change.
author: Tien N.

description:
My favorite restaurant in SF. And I have been to plenty. 

Aesthetic is awesome, food and service.

Deviled eggs with the fried oyster are a must! Lobster roll is also the bomb. Don't let these broke, tasteless people sway you otherwise lol
author: Chelsea K.

description: Beautiful place to eat oyster and drink a good wine. They have a Happy hour for $1.50 each oyster!! Amazing I love it
author: Stephanny D.

description:
I loved it here, & I hardly ever eat oysters!

Front room, middle room, back room.

The front room is warm & boisterous, w a full bar running along the left, & tables aligning the opposite wall on the right.  The middle room has a much smaller bar, & is far more low key than the front room.  The back room was hosting a private event, so I couldn't check it out.  The palm tree, pineapple, island/plantation decor is fabulous.  This theme runs throughout each room, & the vibe is very old school, very relaxed, while still possessing an element of sophistication.

Frank Sinatra meets Tommy Bahama, & they get along swimmingly.

The menu continues the elegant vibe...foie gras toast.  Caviar.  And of course, oysters for days.  

Unfortunately, I didn't have caviar this visit.  But the foie gras toast, & the oysters, were fantastic.  I can also recommend the seafood bisque, perfect on a typical SF chilly night, & the crab & lobster cake.  Perfectly moist, w the crab & lobster presence well balanced.

Service impressively balances that tightrope between polished & easygoing...which completely befits the whole culture of Leo's.

Another successful addition to the Park Tavern family.
And a nice escape for a couple of hours.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Tots, oyster carbonara and lobster roll are all you need to leave like a happy little fat kid from the cupcake store.  Would I come on my own dime? ehhh maybe if I were some lucky rich kid that got blessed with a crap ton of money to sit in an office to SAVE THE WORLD WITH TECHNOLOOOGYYY YEUHH...but since I'm not it would be pretty hard to come back and pay for it myself unless it's a special occasion.
author: Vince L.

description:
I love them raw.  I love them cheap.  I love them simple, with just lemon and hot sauce.

But I don't love to share them with the table next to me.

If you eat at Leo's and want a little privacy, try to avoid the front room and head on to the back dining room.  Even in the back, you still won't find much privacy, and you're certain to hear every word of conversation from the tables next to you.

Don't get me wrong, oysters were good, albeit pricy, but it's the other small dishes that were just marginally good and not really worth the money that I paid.  I guess someone has to pay for the décor.

The place has a nice vibe, but I can get the same oysters for half the price elsewhere.
author: Ron L.

description:
My husband and I had one night in San Francisco and dinner reservations at Mr. Jiu's, so we wanted to squeeze one more dining experience in before heading home. Leo's Oyster Bar suited us nicely. We walked in around 6pm on a Tuesday, and were able to be seated at a table as long as we were out by 8pm. No problem.

The decor is really pretty, especially the wallpaper. We ordered half a dozen west coast oysters and chilled king crab legs, as well as a martini and champagne for pairing. The oysters were really great, but I loved the king crab leg the most. The shellfish was served with standard shallot mignonette, but also a spicy spiked Japanese mayo, which I preferred on the king crab leg.

Overall, a very pleasant aperitif experience.
author: Meghan A.

description:
This is another place I wish I could just Live in. I enjoy coming here for boozy lunch during the week or a quick happy hour after work. 

I am so in-love with Leo's because it takes me to Miami. The decor never get's old and the service is great. My menu favorites so far are the deviled eggs and oysters on the half shell for apps. Shrimp roll for main and bubble bath or liquid lunch for cocktail (the pickle medley that comes with the liquid lunch is heaven on earth) Every time I order the liquid lunch, I remain buzzed for the rest of the day...not sure how one drink can do that. Magic I guess. 
Last time my friend got the tater tots and they were the fanciest gourmet tater tots I've ever seen so I'm definitely trying next time. I got my eye on the Clam Chowder too for warming up on foggy days.
Every time I come the staff has been pretty accommodating with seating us even if we walk in without a reservation. THE ONLY reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that it's just pretty spendy, but, this is SF...
author: Shayan S.

description:
What an amazing spot! Seriously one of the best places to eat in the city. Definitely the best in financial district if you're looking for fresh, tastey seafood, with a great vibe. Super good music playing, friendly and good looking staff, great wine/cocktails/champagne. 
Today I had the lobster roll which comes with a spicy aoili and a side of fries. I had the dark chocolate moose for desert. Words can't describe the pleasure... 

This is a good spot for a date, casual co-workers on lunch, after work drinks, whatever works honestly. This is all around a great spot to know.
My server was Rob, who was friendly, funny, and super cute tbh. 
The host is super sweet and cute, the manager is also such a nice woman. 
Kathrine at the oyster bar was working super hard while I ate at the "raw bar" she was friendly and accommodating. 
Not to gush over everyone, but I am just totally impressed by everyone that has served me here.
I've never had anything short of a perfect experience.

Intimate. Fun. Fresh. Friendly. Incredibly tasty.

Doesn't get much better than this!

Definitely one of my go-to spots, forever.
If you don't try it, you're missing out.
author: Kayla C.

description:
Came here for lunch, it was OK. We were seated in the back, I didn't particularly like the decor: the art deco theme with leafy-patterned wallpaper, gold-colored lights, and their cabana chairs. Hip music was playing way too loud for the lunch hour. It's not a good place for a business lunch because it's so noisy in here. 

Their fries are spectacular, especially with that spicy aioli tip. I also had the seafood bisque, it was OK. The lobster roll was not worth $34. In fact, I didn't think it was anything special, and you can probably pay half the price for something tastier at a cheaper place. The lobster meat in the sandwich was quite chunky though, so good chunks of lobster, lots of meat, and not "watered down" with mayo. 

I didn't try their oysters, because at $5-7 a piece, I'd rather go to Hog Island or some other $1 oyster place.
author: Jennifer W.

description: They have an awesome happy hour with $1 oysters and $25 bubbles- super cute place with a trendy vibe. Decent wine list and the other food is very nice- the salmon is very good as well as the corn soup (the jalapeño poppers weren't that great). The tea leaf salad was overdressed so probably wouldn't get that again. Overall, good service and great oysters!
author: Sashini W.

description:
Came here to grab lunch with some friends.   We had a party of 8 people.  They were very accommodating shuffled some seatings around so we could all sit together. 

Took out waitress over 20 minutes to take our orders. We literally had to ask for everything. Customer service was not all that great.

We ordered a few things to try and thought it was alright expect for the oysters and seafood bisque. They're really worth the try.

Their little Leo oysters and Eloise were tiny but delicious. 

Clam chowder was way too salty and didn't taste any clam. 

Pickled vegetables. This was good.

Fries for the kids

Chamomile tea: took awhile for it to come out.
Brooks cider was alright.
author: Hollie H.

description:
I like the idea of Leo's Oyster Bar far more than the actual food experience; it's masterminded by the same folks that head Park Tavern, of which I absolutely can't get enough. And it was hard to miss the many, many social media pics of not just their lobster roll, but the tropical, chic tiki bar-esque decor. I wanted in. 

Between the four of us, I'd be surprised if there was something we didn't sample between the raw bar and a variety of both Small and Large Plates. I thought the deviled eggs were great, the fries crisp as can be, & the complimentary espresso mousse for dinner was exceptionally rich. Tater Tots and Crab and Lobster Cake were heavy, but not on flavor. The crab or shrimp cocktail didn't have a taste or texture I would come back for. With these negatives, I wasn't surprised when the lobster roll turned out to be just meh. 

The decor is a gorgeous throwback to an era decidedly not ours (hats off to Ken Fulk for his vision.) And the few cocktails on our table were something to write home about. I wish I felt as enamored with the food as I am with the aesthetic here.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Overrated and overpriced. Came here with two other friends for drinks and appetizers and was very disappointed. 

I'll start with the good: I will give them props for the design/ambiance. The decor was cute and inviting, albeit the lighting was so dark you could hardly appreciate it.

Now, the bad:

Though our own fault, we didn't reserve ahead of time and knew we'd end up eating at the bar, which is typically a-ok with us. However, the bartender who served us was rude and short with us the entire time which didn't make for an enjoyable experience.

We each had a drink and ordered the following appetizers:
-Mookie Blues Oysters
-Ahi Tuna Crudo
-House-Made Tater Tot bites
-Wild Mushroom Toast bites
-Farro Risotto

The crudo and tater tots were yummy but the rest was unsatisfying. Additionally, all of the portions were TINY. Usually when my friends and I go out for "drinks and apps" and order 4-5 dishes we're full enough to skip dinner, but this was absolutely was not the case at Leo's. We were so hungry we went and got burgers and fries afterwards! The section labeled "Bites to Share" says that each serving comes with 4 pieces, and each piece is literally ONE BITE. Even the crudo which wasn't labeled under the "bites" section of the menu was one bite per person. The risotto entree was also quite small and was not an appropriate size for a main dish. 

The worst part was the tab - after tax and tip the bill came out to over $150 for not enough food to fill the stomach of a 5 year old. 

The combination of small portions, subpar food, high prices and bad service is a recipe for boycott. Unless I hear this is Jimmy Garoppolo's new favorite restaurant in SF, your girl will not be back.
author: Jessie K.

description:
Tucked away in S Fran's Financial district, this is a veritable gem, actually three gems. Leo's is the first then in a back room is the Hideaway then beyond that the tiki bar.  

The cocktails are superb and the menu is both clever and well executed.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
My friends took me here for a late birthday get together. This place is great for happy hour and to hang out in the FIDI. It was super crowded so make sure you call ahead of time to save a table. started off with some drinks, we ordered the Rose, an our server was absolutely wonderful!  

We ordered a little bit of everything and shared the plates. We started off with Leo's Deviled Eggs with wing fried oysters, and they were great! The spicy sauce that came with it paired really well along with the fried oyster. We ordered two orders of fries because who doesn't love fries? 

We then ordered a dozen raw oysters, house made tater tots, Leos Louie with gem lettuce, ahi tuna, braised short ribs wild mushroom goat cheese and truffle , crab and lobster cake, and Japanese Hamachi. 

I have to say all our orders for absolutely wonderful. The flavors and paring with each dish was great. The portions were good enough to share between the three of us. The raw oysters were fresh and creamy. The braised short ribs were cooked just right that the meat would just fall off the  bone. 

For dessert we had the Pineapple Sundae, and lemon mousse. All cooked perfectly and display was awesome. I would effeminately come back to eat and have happy hour. I do have to say the place is very cramp .
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Not your typical "old man" oyster bar, has a light hip feel to the room. 

Food was on-point with lots of snacks to share over Cool cocktails. 

Really tight restaurant concept that gets all the details right to fit into a cohesive package.  Everything looks, tastes, and sounds bang-on!
author: Mark G.

description:
Mixed bag

Service, oysters, deviled egg with oyster, were all thumbs up - 4 stars

Housemade tater tots - 3 stars - neither good nor bad

House sparkling rose - 3 stars - nothing wrong with the taste but priced a bit richly for a Cremant (definitely fair at the hh price of $10/glass - rather absurd for over $70 per bottle....remember, it's a Cremant that sell for under $20/bottle)

The rest - 2 stars - boring and WAY overpriced:
1. Lamb Tartare - zero flavor - how is this possible? it's lamb!  lamb naturally has a strong flavor - and what about the spices that normally goes with a tartare?
2. Crab cake - snooze....
3. foie gras toast - another snoozer....
author: Lev E.

description:
Out of everywhere in SF, I chose to celebrate my birthday at Leo's Oyster Bar... and I would say it was a great decision.

We had reservations for 8:15 on December 1st, however we arrived early and the host was so kind to find us a seat at the main bar. We had cocktails while we waited for our table to be ready. The restaurant seemed full, and busy but certainly not packed.

I had a dirty vodka martini, and it was delicious. My boyfriend had a maitai for some reason??? He enjoyed the drink but didn't love the glass it came in, I told him real men drink bourbon... but thats a whole different story. The bartenders were efficient and moved quickly. Everyone was very pleasant.

I was happy when the host, came and lead us to a table in the back room. (Same room I was in, the last time I came to Leo's in October.)
As usual, the decor was beautiful, warm and inviting. We were quickly greeted by the server, who happened to be the same one as I got last time. The girl with the tattoos, Celiss.

She was very nice, attentive and described most of the menu to us, right away. I immediately knew what I was going to order. 

Though I love oysters, I very much prefer East Coast oysters since they tend to be more shallow and saltier. I did see they had oysters from PEI  but I decided to skip them since I am going back to NYC in a few weeks where I'll live off of Oysters for 7 days.

I really wanted Tuna Tar Tar, but she kindly told me that they didn't have any, (bummer) but she recommended I try the Ahi Tuna Apple dish. I started with that, and fell in love. The tuna was very fresh and the apple was crisp. I've never had the combination of the 2, but I am glad I got to try it. Great recommendation! Kudos to the chef for a delicious appetizer.

I spotted bone marrow on the menu and of course I had to order it. I love bone marrow and actively complain that I don't eat it nearly enough since no restaurants seem serve it, which I understand. Every time I see it on a menu, I always order it because if they have it, chances are that they know to cook it. The bone marrow was delicious, they serve it with toast and it spreads on like butter. I wanted to order 9 additional orders to go.

We had some more drinks, I don't even remember what they were.
But I'm sure they were tasty.

For the entree, I decided to go with the Short Rib and I 100% made the right choice. The short rib was tender, the potatoes were tasty and the butter that came with it, was delicious. I could literally bathe in a bathtub of this Short Rib with a potato puree, and I don't care what anyone thinks of this.

My boyfriend got the salmon, which was super fresh. It was cooked to a perfect Medium. I love that they didn't over cook it.

For dessert we had the apple crisp, along with the bittersweet chocolate mouse topped off with gold (for a real princess of course...) in the cutest pineapple shaped dish, along side a birthday candle.
We also had a creme de mint, after dinner cocktail which was mixed to perfection by the lovely bartender, Matt who never fails to mix a perfect drink.

I over all had a great time and I would recommend Leo's to any of my friends, neighbors, friendamies, uber drivers, colleages, etc etc etc...

Thank you for the continuous warm hospitality and delicious meals/drinks.
author: Tati C.

description: The back 'tiki room', the French fries and amazing aioli sauce, the little Leo oysters from the Puget Sound, the hamachi, the butterfish, a very lovely evening in an uplifting room with fabulous (yes 80's) music.
author: Sheryl F.

description: The back room is among my top 5 date spots!  The music and service is always .  10/10 be back for oysters and pineapple dessert trays
author: Kai Q.

description:
3.5 stars

Oysters. You either love them or you hate them and I love them. My friend wanted to check out this place and I was not opposed, especially when she showed me the cool wallpaper this place has (which you can buy online by the way). We got a few of the oysters and they were all really good, but my favorite are the baked ones. The raw ones were fresh and briny (which I like), but they were kind of small. This place was kind of dark and loud, so don't expect to have a deep conversation here.

Overall, they oysters were good, but it was too pricey for my taste.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Service was great, food was disappointing...
We ordered hamachi, lamb tartare, fougrue toasts, oysters, lobster roll and short ribs.
Hamachi was tasteless and pieces were very small. 
Lamb tartare had a lack of spices,  wasn't salty nor spicy and therefore was tasteless as well, also meat didn't look fresh.
Fougrue toasts didn't have any fougrue... it had some kind of concentrated salty fougrue paste.
Oysters is the only dish that we really like, since they didn't have to do anything with it, they were kind of small though. 
Lobster roll was cold with some tasteless French fries.
Short ribs were chewy and again LACK OF SPICES!

For $30-$35 for the entree, I was expecting a much better quality food...

Definitely overpriced place, Not recommended for dinner, Ok just for drinks after work.
author: Roman L.

description:
Eat here asap. It reminds me a little of Indochine in NYC. 

The miso trout (lunch menu) is like an Asian niçoise. I love that word... #niçoise ! Fries, well I nearly slapped my dining-mate's hand to get at them. The deviled egg, can you believe it? They put a fried oyster in it! That's some good interspecies mingling on my tastebuds.
author: Nia D.

description: LOVED this place. Food was on-point, even while I was on an elimination diet. The server could not have been more pleasant, knowledgeable and accommodating. Atmosphere was awesome, as was the music. Amazing playlist at the perfect volume. Went on a Monday night and it was pretty chill. If you get there at 7 you can park at the meters. If not, there's a crazy expensive but convenient garage down the street (that closes at 9 on weekdays). Def check this place out. Sooooo good.
author: Maria F.

description:
My husband took me here for our anniversary dinner. Our friend was able to get last minute reservation at 6pm. For a Thursday evening, this place was busy. Cute interior. We sat in the front room next to the bar. Very small and we were all tightly packed. Dimmed lights with candle on table. Felt intimate. I heard there's 2 more dining rooms in the back. 

Our server was very attentive, sweet, friendly & helpful. Triple A plus for her service. I forgot her name. We told her it was our first time here. She recommended a few items for us and got us started. Their food is tapas style. Small portion. We ordered quite a few items - side of pickled veggies, toasted spiced nuts, two orders of wing fried oyster deviled eggs, 8 specialty raw oysters, foie gras toast, madai snapper with puffed vermicelli, clam chowder, tater tots, and shared a lobster roll with fries. 

Mmmm, our favorites were the deviled eggs, foie gras toast & fries. Yes, the fries were addictive. Perfectly thin, crisp & salted. Yum. Foie gras was very delicious. The fried oyster crunchiness paired with deviled eggs is the greatest combo ever. Mmms, our taste buds got excited. Our eyes were LIT!! Next, the clam chowder & tater tots was also very good. We weren't really into the madai snapper. It was thinly sliced. The puffed vermicelli didn't go too well with it. Last, our main entree was the lobster roll. After eating all the other items, we were full by now. Good chunks of lobster in warm toasted bread. Again, those fries...yum. My tummy is growling right now just by typing this review at work.

They raw oysters were good but not spectacular. Nothing really stand out. We were able to try the specialty topped with uni and caviar. The oysters were too small that we didn't really had time to enjoy the taste. It was gone in an instant when it gets in our mouth. We did taste the saltiness and sweetness from the oyster.

Our server gave us a mousse chocolate for dessert, compliments from the chef. It was creamy and good. You've got to try the garden cocktail. That was one creamy'licious cocktail I've ever had. I had two of these. It had the right amount of alcohol. Not too strong. Not too sweet. 

Overall, the food & experience was wonderful. Our server was great. Service was top notch. Water were filled constantly. Napkins were folded each time when we got up to use the restroom. It was a very expensive dinner, but it was worth it. We had an enjoyable anniversary dinner. We will be back for another special occasion.
author: Amy H.

description:
2.5 Stars

Great ambiance!

Great drinks!

So why the low rating, you ask?

The food and service was not up to par. It was not as good as expected and left us unsatisfied that night. We ended up going to another place right after we walked out of this restaurant. 

The food that we ordered:

- Raw oysters = Kusshi from WA ($4.5 per oyster). The only good thing that night. Fresh and sweet. 

- Japanese Hamachi ($17) with charred avocado and sprinkle with sea salt. Overpriced and could use more seasoning. 

- Class steak tartare ($20) - with uni and marrow. The wasabi sauce on the steak tartare masks the uni and marrow. What a disappointment!

- Black Cod ($34) - with squash, pomegranate, and spinach. Once again they need to season their fish. It was bland and boring. Portion was also small. I'd say skip it!

I'm glad I made a reservation for this place to be in the quiet room; otherwise you'll end up in the main entrance that is cramped and stuffy. Also, did I mention very LOUD!!!

Another new restaurant off my bookmarked list and definitely not a place I want to revisit. Kthanksbye!
author: Owie N.

description:
I love Leo's. This is my favorite place to take people for a special night out or just a "treat yo' self" kind of day. 

Vibes.
Restaurant decor and ambiance is very important to me. Leo's sets a beautiful dining stage-- from the high ceilings and beautiful floral wallpaper to the casual yet chic outfits of the wait staff. I immediately feel comfortable, cozy, and taken care of as soon as I sit down. 

Drinks. 
I believe that the menu of cocktails is very good (so other dinner companions tell me). But I cannot bring myself to order anything but the Garden Party-- a light, aromatic, egg-white drink with gorgeous floral garnish. I drink two every time I dine here. 

Bites. 
Raw oysters-- Fresh, delicious, garnished beautifully. 
Deviled egg with fried oyster-- They are expensive ($6 for 1) but so worth it. I always wish I could eat a whole plate of these. 
Hot lobster roll-- OMG so good. And if you want to split with a friend they will make you two smaller lobster rolls. It's precious. Comes with french fries and dynamite sauce (it's all in the name). 
Clam chowder-- I used to live in the Boston area and can attest to its deliciousness. 
Braised Short Rib-- Falls apart and melts in your mouth. 

I would eat here once a week if my pocketbook and waistline could stand it! Keep it up, Leo's.
author: Carson S.

description: This place is super cute and the oysters are beyond tasty! Carlos was our waiter and he was very attentive. Amazing staff and amazing food!!! Great ambiance as well!!! Be sure to make a reservation too
author: Julie G.

description: Nice place with decent food. A tad pricey for small portions. Be prepared to wait.... and then wait a bit more.
author: Brad S.

description:
Food:
-Oysters were wonderful - we ordered 12 total, they were averaging about $3/each, but were from all over the world - Prince Edward Island, New Brunswick, Washington, Maine, etc. They were delicious, and fun to try a variety from different places. 
-Foie Gras toast - TOO SALTY. Don't get this one. My bf and I love foie gras and uni, but man this dish was just not meant to be.
-Japanese Hamachi with avocado, sea salt, and scallion - YUM. This was a good one. Not the best hamachi I ever had, but pretty damn good.
-Leo's Louie combo (crab and shrimp) with gem lettuce, mache, radish, fennel, tobiko and egg. This was a great dish, really fresh ingredients. The dressing was a little too pungent and sour for my taste though.
-Lobster roll with Uni butter, brioche and French fries - YUM. I hope you get this one. We shared every plate for the night, and what's great about this restaurant is that they just split the plate ahead of time for you. French fries great too. I didn't really taste the uni in the butter, but hey, it was an awesome lobster roll overall. 

Drinks:
Fantastic, actually. Probably one of the highlights of my night! My bf got the Mai Tai which was delicious, and came in this really cute tiki-themed cup. I got the Skinny Dip (vodka, aperol, watermelon, lime, tonic popsicle) which was fun - never had a drink with a popsicle in it before! Drinks were on the medium-strong side, and definitely worth $15/each. If I had to come here again, it would be for the drinks.

Ambiance:
Very cute inside, but hopefully you'll get to sit in the main dining area. We were shoved in this weird back room, with no windows. It was a weird experience. I didn't like being put back there - it made me feel forgotten about. Anyway, decorations are still cute in the back room, and overall the restaurant is super loud, and dark, which is frustrating.

Service:
Although very friendly overall, I had one disappointing interaction. A lady who came to bus our empty plates from our table, asked us how we liked the dish. We told her that the Foie Gras toast was too salty. She said, "I'll go talk to the chef about it." We never got an apology, or anything from the chef. That was disappointing. I mean, it's great they said they'd do something about it, but even more disappointing when you anticipate it and they DON'T. 

Was it worth it?
Not for $135/person. I won't return. I know I'm being nit-picky, but if I'm paying that much, I would like to have a table in the main room, with service that follows up with their customers. Drinks were great though, so do remember to try one of their awesome cocktails.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Yum, yum, YUM. I recommend a stop in at Leo's. 
Do make a reservation in advance.

Things to eat:
1. ($16) Wild mushroom, goat cheese, and truffle toast: very tasty flavors. I believe it might come with 3 pieces, so ask to add on a 4th if you're a party of even numbers.

2. ($6/oyster) Deviled egg with wing fried oyster: really good flavors, maybe a bit more of a kick than expected, leaves you needing a bit of water but worth trying out

3. ($16) Smoked tuna dip: a nice treat, the roe are a fun addition to the tuna spread

4. Oysters....yeah...oysters

-Great service
-Cool environment though a bit cramped
-Get ready to drop some $$$s
author: Rachel R.

description:
I love this Leo's oyster bar. Talk about great service and food from the becoming to the end. I didn't know they actually have a private tavern in the back room with a small amount of tables. 
At first I was wondering why are we walking past the restaurant than we went through these doors and than we arrived at the tavern. 

We tried every type of oysters they had on the menu and than some. They know their oysters and I have to say if you happen to be in San Francisco and looking for a place to eat some good oysters this place is it. 

As busy as they are I recommend you call and make reservations.
author: Kalani S.

description:
I love this place.  Their oysters are the BEST in the Bay Area.  You're going to pay for the quality of the food, but I'm happy to do that.  I've only been here for lunch which is fantastic.  I had the lobster roll this past visit with a glass of Verdiccio.  We had some of the specialty oysters as well as the plain ones too.  

The atmosphere is a fun, 50's style sort of vibe, which reminds me of Mad Men.
author: Alyse S.

description:
If your in SF and your looking for an oyster bar, I would without a doubt have to say the Leo's Oyster Bar is the only place that I would ever recommend. First of all I still can't get over the adorable decor, I really felt like I was almost transported back to a cool little cocktail bar in the 1950's in Hawaii. It had an amazing almost island vibe. 
I am a bloody mary gal, so I ordered their bloody mary. It was delicious and exactly what I was looking for. We also ordered a bottle of wine as well. They had a pretty killer wine list both by the glass and bottle. 
To eat we got two dozen oysters and got a few of every one they were offering that day. We also got each of their composed oysters, some cherry stone clams as well as some pickled king crab and house made pickles. Everything was absolutely delicious, the oysters were fresh and shucked to perfection, the composed oysters were perfectly balanced. Service was attentive with out being intrusive. The only downfall is that we all got there right after 2:30 which is when they stop serving their lunch menu and only serve items from their raw bar. 
Next time I am in San Francisco I will be sure to head back to Leo's to get more yummy oysters and this time get to try their delicious sounding lunch or dinner menu!
author: Roxy H.

description:
Everything is so well done at Leo's. From the plants outside to the gorgeous massive doors to the wallpaper inside to the pictures in the frame - i could keep going- all the details have been so thoughtfully and tastefully done. The design is so spot on. We came for lunch so I got to appreciate all the details in great lighting. There were some high ceilings with skylights and it made for fantastic ambiance. 

Upon entering I was a little nervous the place was small and already pretty full. It was pretty cold and the only table available was the one next to the door. To my surprise, the hostess took us to the back where they had two more back rooms still wonderfully decorated and on theme. 

The lunch menu offered a complete raw bar menu, hot oyster starters, appetizers, soups, salads, sandwiches, and entrees all wonderfully seafoodcentric. The fries and the "dynamite" sauce was amazing! I'm guessing it's a mix of siracha and mayo and little something extra? It's damn good. 
For starters we ordered some lil leo oysters, and some other creek oysters and they were delicious and fresh. Nothing unusual to their oysters. They did serve it with a green chile vodka sauce but that wasn't my thing. 

I had a Leo's Louie salad with king crab. It wasn't what I was expecting in terms of looks but it tasted delicious! It came with a lot of side dressing but the salad already tasted so flavorful on its own. My coworkers got lobster rolls, and tea leaf salad. Both looked delicious. I'm def gonna have to come back for dinner service and drinks.
author: Veronica L.

description: I hear fern walls are very 2017, which means Leo's was ahead of the trend. It really is like stepping into a time warp here - there's been a lot of thought put into the space. Unfortunately, that time warp also applies to stomachs - while I really enjoyed my Bubble Bath cocktail, the items we shared were overwhelmingly rich, and yet I didn't feel full at the end of lunch...just groggy.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Oysters are good but I think they are pricey since it's in financial district. We paid $50 for a dozen of different oysters. Perhaps You can get cheaper from swan oysters depot which is $30 for a dozen. 
The lobster rolls and the foie gras toast are both good.
author: YingTung W.

description: I finally went back - I ordered the king crab salad, dressing on the side. My lunch companion ordered a seafood burger, I think shrimp and scallop.  All I can really say for certain is this chef LOVES pepper  Again, I was served crab covered in pepper.   I mean really, I ordered a crab salad because I wanted to taste crab, NOT PEPPER.   I had to send it back.  The dressing as well, loaded with pepper.  My dining companion said his burger also had too much pepper to enjoy.  I might go back in for a drink, but not the food - the food could use a taster with a palate imho
author: Suzy Q.

description:
Clam chowder..... AMAZING.
Little Leo's oysters..... AMAZING.
The risotto...... AMAZING.
The clams.... AMAZING!!!!!
Everything here was so wonderful. The decor was superb. The wait staff was so helpful. The check presenter was so cute!!!! I love the verde chile sauce they serve on the side for the oysters....ugh!! Who would have thought it would pair so well?!
COME HAVE AN AMAZING EXPERIENCE HERE
author: Maria C.

description:
The challenge: two Asian girls with a giant appetite. 
The problem: A table that barely fits more than 2 plates.
The order: about 8 different dishes. Plus drinks.
Henderson, our waiter, was up to the challenge. 

I came here the other night with my friend. When I called to make a reservation, the host asked if we were celebrating anything. Uhh...friendship, booze, and food?? But it's a nice touch that they ask. When we arrived, they brought us to the far back side. I mean. Far. We passed three thresholds to get to this back tiki-style room that evidently used to be outdoors, but they turned into a private event space. By the end of the night, I think they showed about 5 different groups the space. Somewhat awkward for us...as after the other party left, we were the only ones there. So...we're part of "selling" the space for them? Hurm.

Hamachi Crudo: Delicious. Hamachi was very fresh, and the charred avocado was buttery.

Oysters (Hammersley, Hog Island, Little Leo, Olympia): Good general assortment. It got better and better, until the Olympia...which to me was too small and didn't have much flavor. Sad.

House Tater Tot: Delicious. Seriously get this. It's got the fry of the tater tot, but with some delicious tapenade on top that's just yum.

Salmon Tartare: Really good, and pretty nice portion. Very light and not fishy at all!

Crab Cake: Bacon across the lightest horseradish ever. So delicious. And literally fell apart. 

Lobster Roll: Probably just as good as the lobster rolls at Chelsea Market in NYC. Buttered roll was delicious, and it was crammed full of lobster. Yum. And hella generous with the fries.

Mussels: Very filling and SO good. The bread accompanying it wasn't as great, but we started using the fries...which was worth it. I kind of wish the bread was thicker and just sauce-sopping. Mmm...delicious. 

Walnut Cookies: They gave us these (perhaps because we became their showpiece?), and they were pretty good. Not sure if I'd order it though.

Blood Orange Creamsicle Float: Delicious. Just yummy. If you're into creamsicles, get this. If you have a small child (or are one at heart) order it to go with your meal. It's just good. 

We also had a honey gin-based drink, which was really strong and very delicious. Overall. Really nice meal. The service, even though we were in the back, was enough but not annoyingly so. We never felt neglected.
author: Lily W.

description:
My friend and I stopped by here for after dinner nibbles. We thought that there would be a wait since the dining and bar area looked crowded. However, we were able to get seated immediately in their cute back room. We followed our friendly hostess past the dining area, past the kitchen, past the restrooms, through a discreet doorway, which lead us to a whole other dining area.  Seating was a bit cozy, but the vibe was great (loved the bumping '90s-'00s music). Our server was very warm, attentive, and friendly.

As we waited for our foie gras toast and bone marrow, we definitely got food envy watching the raw seafood platters being brought out. We agreed that next time we come back, we definitely Our food was absolutely delicious. The foie gras toast had the perfect ratio of toast to foie gras, with just the right amount of chives to cut and balance out the richness of the foie. The bone marrow was great for sharing, with each scoop of intensely flavored fatty scoop enjoyed on a piece of toast.

Upon initially looking at their menu and seeing other people's food being brought out, I wanted to "get alllll the things", but obviously couldn't. Eagerly anticipating the next time I get to come back and try more of their delicious food!
author: Gloria S.

description:
Oysters were phenomenal. We got to sample everything they had on their raw menu.
Drinks were on point. 
Felt like the seating area was a bit too dark and squished, but other than that I will definitely return for some aphrodisiacs
author: Kehaulani K.

description: Definitely a super instagram bait location! The decor is just amazing! I can't imagine how beautiful the front room would be when it's sunny. I ordered their ribeye salad! I normally do not like salads but the dressing that they used was super yummy! Everyone who worked there are super nice and friendly. They even offered to give me a tour of the place because there are two other rooms in the back with completely different decor!
author: Jenny D.

description:
I love watching reruns of The Golden Girls. Space cadet Rose (Betty White) and southern vixen Blanche (Rue McClanahan) are my favs. I mean, I don't know anyone who makes being a slut as classy as Blanche does - do you? I mean her initials: Blanche Elizabeth Devereaux spell B-E-D for phuck sakes.

Walking into Leo's Oyster Bar reminded me of The Golden Girls with its quirky, retro garden patio party theme with non-instagrammable lighting. More specifically, it made me think of a place one of Blanche's men would take her before their all night rendezvous. Gotta wine and dine to get in that cookie jar...

Our Plan A (The Morris) fell through since their opening was delayed so my friend and I decided to go to Leo's Oyster Bar after having sat in our bookmarks for months. 

Don't even think about coming here without reservations unless you come super early and sit at the bar. It's super cramped and tables are literally inches apart so only come here in pairs. Finding street parking was pretty easy on a Saturday night. 

My friend and I arrived early for our 5:30 pm reservations. We were told our table wasn't ready so we grabbed a drink at the bar which has the most uncomfortable wicker (?) bar stools. I was thanking my lucky stars that the vintage stool didn't break in half when I sat on it.

~ * ~ D R I N K S ~ * ~
*Garden Party: Hendrick's gin, jardescsa, egg white, fresh herbs ($13): http://bit.ly/2e3FP4Z
 Almost too pretty to drink, the Garden Party was well-balanced and had a good creaminess. 

When are table was ready at The Hideaway Room, we were disappointed with the cocktails there. They were not as visually appealing as the ones at the front bar and didn't taste as good. 
 
*Honey Lynn: Honey infused gin, absolut elyx, lillet, lemon bitters ($14): http://bit.ly/2dIVSl7
The Honey Lynn was their take on a Vesper but there was no honey taste. 

*Banana Daiquiri: Pampero rum, banana liquor, lime, spices ($14): http://bit.ly/2eoZf31
My friend's Banana Daiquiri oddly smelled and tasted like peach schnapps so it was exchanged for something else.

~ * ~ F O O D ~ * ~
As others have mentioned, the food prices are $$$$ which is fine IF the food was amazing. It wasn't.
 
*Oysters & Cherrystone Clams ($3-$5 each): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2dJw0Jz
I only had one of the cherrystone clams which were meaty, tender, and slightly bitter. My friend enjoyed the raw oysters.
 
*Oyster Carbonara w/ crispy pancetta ($5 each): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/2ep1G5S
Too salty. Should have took the advice of other yelpers and skipped this.
 
*Baked Oyster w/ ahi tuna, seaweed, togarashi ($5 each): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/2ecO8LE
Too salty. Again, I should have took the advice of other yelpers and skipped this.
 
*Leo's Deviled Egg w/ wing fried oyster ($5 each): 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2d5wFnq
Love the uber crunchy oyster crowning the deliciously creamy deviled egg. Yah, it was $5 for one bite but it was the perfect luxe bite and we wanted to order more but couldn't. More on that later. 
 
*Salmon Tartar w/ marrow, capers, dill ($16): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/2du6Fy9
My friend thought it was fine but I thought the saltiness of the capers completely overpowered the delicate flavor of the salmon. Plus, the toast points weren't evenly toasted so they were chewy in the center.
 
*Foie Gras Toast w/ ginger, soy, scallion, uni butter ($20): 2.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2e3Fxeo
Foie gras and uni are two of my favorite loves but not in this case. The flavors were muddled and one of the toasts I had was insanely salty while the other piece was too sweet. Ugh, such a letdown since this was the dish I was most excited for.   
 
 ~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~
For the amount that they charge, service was unacceptable. 

Our server was unwelcoming and inattentive. When we were seated in the back lounge, we noticed "The Hideaway" cocktail menu seemed different than the menu in the front. My friend asked our server about it. She coldly replied, "It's ALL the same" and walked away. It wasn't. The lounge area had 4 additional "Hideaway" cocktails but whatever. 
 
Ok, maybe she was having a bad day. 

NOPE, she was noticeably friendlier and chattier with the table next to us. 

After ordering, our server pretty much ignored us. Since we planned on having a full dinner there, we wanted to order more food and our server was nowhere to be found. When she did pass by, she never bothered checking in with us. There were two servers and two other tables at the time so it wasn't busy. 
 
Eff this, why stay somewhere you don't feel welcomed at so we asked another server (who was super sweet) for our bill and bounced to have dinner elsewhere. 
 
Going in, I knew this place would be pricey but at $93 PER A PERSON for 2 drinks each and light apps which was literally 7-8 mediocre bites of food is ridiculous. And, to top things off with the absence of service, no thanks.

Unless your sugar daddy or a filthy rich friend is paying, Leo's Oyster Bar is a total skip!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I love the ambiance here and the food with drinks, compliments well with everything!  

Their crafted cocktails seem, themed!  I got the Island girl and it was tasty fun!

I adore the petite bites here! Get their raw oysters as a starter served with pink champagne mignonette! 

Do get their signature Leo's Deviled Eggs with Fried Wing Oyster.  It is warmly delightful!

Their uni butter toast, topped with foie gras and scallions, is a must get! 

One can't go wrong with any of the crudos!  The hamachi crudo was a sure win for sashimi lovers. 

Our waiter recommended the Mussels En Papillote!  The flavor from the mussels in a tomato soup-like plate with side toasted bread, was perfection for a seafood entree! 

As the London lingo would put it, this spendy bar is swish!
author: Tiffany D.

description: $1 oysters on the happy hour menu - great steal! They were some of the best oysters I've had in the city, just the perfect amount of flavor. Pretty boujee place, would definitely recommend going!
author: Cassy C.

description:
AMAZING service, atmosphere, food, and drinks. I was happy as a clam from the first deviled egg to the final chocolate mousse and port pairing (do not skip it!). 

My only qualm: portions were surprisingly small for the hefty price tags on each drink and dish. I don't mind paying a lot for excellent food, but it was almost comical ordering the 'deviled eggs' and getting 1/2 of one egg. That said, the deviled egg was incredible and I would do it over and over again now that I've experienced it. 

Also, I absolutely loved that they gave us postcards and pens at the end that they mail out for us at the end of the meal; such a cute idea!
author: Claire S.

description:
Went for drinks/oysters with coworkers and I certainly can't complain! The restaurant was very accommodating with the fluctuating number of people in our party - we were a table of 8. 
I was nervous at first that we would be seated in the front of the restaurant, where it was crowded and noisy but tucked away in the back was a quaint, long table by the bar and it was perfect. Unfortunately I don't have any photos as the lighting did not help produce quality photos. 

The prices were pretty steep. I don't think I would have come here and ordered as much as I did if it weren't for the corporate card. We all had about ~2 drinks. I had the The Winter Pimms and a dirty martini. While expensive, they were certainly fresh, delicious and did the trick! The service was impeccable. Always catering to our needs and refilling water, drink orders and bringing oysters in a timely manner. The atmosphere was charming with palm tree leaves across the walls - some coworkers described it as your grandmothers wallpaper in Florida, but I thought it was quite cute!

My oyster knowledge is not quite as extensive as my coworkers did most of the ordering. We tried 4 different kinds - one we all agreed was not the best and we got a surplus of our favorite two. 

While I can't comment on the quality of the entrees, I highly suggest coming here if you have money to spend before dinner on drinks and apps!
author: Maddy O.

description:
Made same day reservations for 6pm on a Friday for 2 people 

Ambiance - 4 stars. Definitely make a reservation for the back rooms. The main room in the front was ridiculously loud and crowded. We were in the first back room and the tables were tiny but servers did a very good job coursing out the meal so everything fit on the table. 

Service - 5 stars. Our waitress was friendly and knowledgeable and service was good and fast. 

Drinks - 5 stars

Food - 3 stars. Bone marrow app and combo louie were good. Deviled eggs and baked oysters were meh. Tuna carpaccio tea leaf salad was reallly disappointing and not at all what we were expecting

Value - 3 stars. Was over $150 for two drinks and a few apps. We felt the service level matched the price but not the quality of food

Tempted to come back bc there were a few other things on the menu that looked good but probably won't
author: Sarina Y.

description:
Ever since Leo's Oyster Bar opened, I've been wanting to go here. I believe they don't take same day reservations on OpenTable, so that's always been a deterrent. (I don't like waiting, so I tend to gravitate towards places that take reservations.)

On Wednesday, August 24th, I was having a drink down the street with Peter L. He said Leo's was a few doors down and it didn't look too busy. Perfect time to drop by, right?! We stopped in around 7:45pm for dinner. They told us it would be about a 20 min wait. I asked them to text me when our table was ready since we were going to grab a drink elsewhere. They happily obliged. About 20 mins later, I got the text. We were seated around 8:15pm.

Raw Bar:
*Kumamoto - CA ($4.25 ea) ×2
*Peter's Point - MA ($4 ea) ×2
*Diamonds and Pearls: oyster and caviar ($10 ea) ×2

Gotta get some oysters at an oyster bar, right?! I'm not super versed in oysters, but I know I like kumamotos. We just randomly picked Peter's point cuz of Peter's name. I chose the caviar oysters since I love that combination. All oysters were fresh with a nice clean, ocean flavor. Yum!

Regular Menu:
*Leo's deviled egg: with wing fried oyster ($5)
*Baked oyster, ahi tuna, seaweed and togarashi ($5)
*Crab and lobster cake, cucumber and horseradish ($17)
*Toast: Foie gras, ginger soy, scallions and uni butter ($20)
*Seafood bisque with lobster, king crab and rock shrimp ($19)
*New england lobster roll, cultured uni butter, brioche and french fries ($32)

Peter and I tend to over order, so yes, the two of us ordered all this. The deviled egg and baked oyster were fun. I did like the play on the deviled egg. I love crab cakes, so I had to try the crab and lobster cake. Full of seafood, but I found the texture on the inside to be a little too mushy. It was contrasted by the crispy exterior. The foie gras toast was delicious! So rich and decadent! There is a slight sweetness to the toast, which I wasn't expecting, but I didn't mind it much. (I'm not a huge fan of sweet and savory together.) I loved the bisque! Creamy and full of seafood flavor! I thought the lobster roll was okay, but I was super full by the time it came out. I just remember not tasting the uni butter. Since I adore uni, I wanted the flavor to be stronger.

Dessert & Wine:
*Blood orange creamsicle float ($7)
*Blanc de blancs, pierre moncuit-delos, grand cru, le mesnil-sur-oger, champagne NV ($85)
*Brut, domaine carneros, napa valley, california 2012 ($60)

What's dinner without drinks?! I didn't want dessert, but Peter did, so he ordered the float. I remember taking a sip and thinking it was okay, but I'm not really a dessert person.
