I definitely enjoyed the bubbly, but we totally drank the bottles backwards. We should have started with the brut and then gone into the blanc de blanc. Regardless, I enjoyed both bottles of bubbly.

Our server was super sweet and fun. We had two seats at the bar, so she was kind enough to split the soup and lobster roll so it was easy to share. I do wish servers would ask before doing that though. Visually, I don't like it when orders are split. This is just a pet peeve of mine. Otherwise, she was awesome and amazing!

So glad I finally tried Leo's Oyster Bar. Any seafood lover will be happy having a meal here.
author: Elena N.

description:
True rating: 2.5

I was quite disappointed with my experience here. I honestly thought it was going to be great by looking at the raving reviews and great food photos. My boyfriend and I went to dinner here, pretty full house, loud and lots of drunkies. It is pretty small, I could barely move.  Staff were attentive and friendly.

We ordered:
Leo's Deviled Egg with Fried Wing Oyster: This was OK, you can't go wrong with eggs.
Oyster Carbonora: VERY salty, there was too much salt, I couldn't enjoy my experience
Salmon Roe Smoked Salmon with Chips: Meh, the chips tasted stale
Foie Gras Toast with Uni Butter: I couldn't taste any uni butter at all and also very salty
Braised Short Ribs with Uni Butter: REALLY salty, the sauce was so salty. The uni butter was good, but i felt the short ribs was just drenched in a salty sauce

Overall, I would not come here again. I was disappointed by the meal and most importantly it was pretty expensive with SMALL portions. I mean if it was GOOD then then I wouldn't mind. I could of went to a michelin star restaurant with the price I paid here. PASS ya'll.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Didn't realize Hawaiian decor could be tre chic... until I found Leo's Oyster Bar. A popular spot for instagrammers (how could you not take pics with those wall coverings?), I celebrated a friend's birthday party here in one of the back rooms. V swanky, i know. A huge part of my experience here was specific to the dinner party (excellent wait staff, endless wine, great company etc.). That being said, I tried to mock up a little food breakdown below:

-Raw Oysters (5/5): Best Oysters I've ever had. They tasted so fresh and flavorful! I loved the sauces they were served with too! A perfect accompaniment.

-Tea Leaf Salad (3/5): Not a huge fan of Tea Leaf Salad in general, this one didn't change my mind. 

-Lobster Roll with Fries (4/5): Omg. Could have been that I was four Pinot Noirs deep (see above re: endless wine) but this Lobster roll was HEAVENLY! The roll was toasted and buttery, the lobster delicious and flavorful, and the fries were just bomb.com.

-Salmon (4/5): Top tier salmon. If I come back I would definitely try a portion for myself!

-Cookies (3/5): In comparison to the incredible savory food the cookies disappointed a little bit. I would opt out of this dessert option

Trendy, unique spot in San Francisco! Gotta say it lives up to the hype!
author: Nicole W.

description:
All I can say is, WOW! I came here with a few co-workers for lunch and we were blown away by the ambiance, service, and delicious food. If I lived in SF, this would absolutely be a regular brunch spot for me! I wanted to stay all day.

Our kind server insisted that the Tea Leaf salad was a must. So, I went ahead and ordered it + added Ahi Tuna Carpaccio + Charred Avocado {yes, charred!!!}. Holy heaven, I want, no wait, NEED this salad in my life on the reg. I wonder if they would send it to AZ?! ;) The Ahi was on the bottom of the salad so it soaked up the delicious dressing. It was so fresh and light. 

We also split a New England Lobster Roll 3 ways because we just couldn't resist. That too was delightful if you're in the mood for a heavier entree. 

I will absolutely recommend Leo's to friends, family, everyone I know who either lives in the city or is just heading there for a visit! Thank you for the excellent experience, Leo's team!
author: Hailey P.

description: You had me at Wendy Peppercorn. Clever, but I got that reference. Appetizers are amazing - Hamachi Crudo please! I've been coming for midday drinks (tried all the cocktails) and the raw bar - oysters!!! No, I don't have a problem with drinking. Ambience is cool. Staff is amazing. Drinks could be stronger even though I have to get back to work after. You get a neat (yes, neat) postcard after that I don't know what to do with. I have a few now. I'll be back.
author: Matt L.

description:
The ambiance at Leo's is awesome. Tucked away in an alley-esque setting, when you walk into Leo's you feel a little more fabulous.

We were seated in the back, The Hideaway. Super cute decor and awesome music (really awesome). It feels really private back there, which is nice! We ordered a dozen oysters, ranging from $3.5 each to close to $5. They were good, tasty, but in my opinion, overpriced (I can't complain too much, given the price of everything in SF). We ordered fries, the mushroom toast, hamachi and bone marrow. Everything tasted great, the Mushroom toast was delicious (throw some truffle on anything and I'm in). I do think that the price vs. portions is a bit skewed ...I understand that it's seafood and I know the drill, trust me, but nothing was mind blowing enough for me to say the price was justified. The fries were really good, if you're into some fries....

Oh, there's more - then we ordered the salmon (large plates), oysters carbonara and the crab cake (yes, it's just 1 crab cake ...no "s"). Again, good food, good ingredients. Very tasty and nothing felt super heavy or made me regret my decision in what I ate that evening, which is always nice. We didn't order any cocktails, but enjoyed some good wine and beer - always a safe bet. They have a good selection of wines/sparkling wines and beer as well.

I would come back, maybe just for some drinks and the cool vibe here. Again, nothing knocked my socks off enough for me to want to come back and have it again or come try more menu items.
author: Nikki R.

description:
Leo's Oyster Bar is a tiny place with a long bar and one row of tables opposite the bar.  The dining room is quite small and other diners are quite close so don't come here expecting to have a private conversation.  That said, the atmosphere is quite lively with craft cocktails and seafood flowing from the bar/raw bar.

The raw bar offers multiple varieties of oysters, crab legs, shrimp and lobster.  Everything we had was fresh and delicious.  Photo included below.

The small plates are also great for sharing and sipping cocktails.  The caviar blinis are especially good.

I wasn't a fan of the tots topped with salt cod.  With all of the fresh seafood available, I didn't enjoy the cured cod.  I would have liked to see caviar or crab in this dish.

The mussels and chorizo were delicious.  Fresh mussels in a spicy sauce served with grilled sourdough.
author: Lance W.

description:
Leo's Oyster bar is a great place to celebrate a special occasion and relax. Their interior decor is a mix of tiki and tropical colorful Cuban details which created a fun, romantic and relaxed vibe. I took my boyfriend here for his birthday and we really enjoyed the following: 

Garden Party cocktails (egg white, gin, fresh herbs and low sugar 

Assorted oysters (if you're either an oyster connoisseur or no nothing about it like me, the wait staff is very knowledgeable and will help you find the right thing for your tastes) 

TEA LEAF CARPACIO TUNA SALAD (this was the best dish of the night!!!! Wow was this a delicious dish. I love the traditional fermented tea leaf salad. Paired with the fresh tuna it went to a whole new level of deliciousness. I highly recommend trying it - an order was great to split for two but you may just want one for yourself! 

Chocolate mousse - it tasted rich and dense with a slight coffee flavor. And they served it with gold flakes in a super cute gold pineapple dish. 

What we also ordered but didn't love as much: 
Bone marrow (sure it was very good but it was not my favorite personally) 

Raw clams (they are super chewy and briney if you like that kind of thing) 

Mussels (I'm a huge fan of mussels and the ones they served were large and hearty but the sauce didn't really permeate the mussels well. I much prefer them at Chez Maman.) 

The service here is very attentive and if you can get a table in one of the back rooms do! It is much quieter back there and relaxed than the front bar area which is a cool area but loud on a Friday night. Overall a lovely experience here!
author: Claire C.

description:
Oyster Freshness, selection, temperature and presentation are all top notch. One of the best Ive experienced.

The small dishes were just OK. Nothing stellar or ground breaking.
Cocktails were decent. The dinner for 3 was quite expensive for  appetizers and drinks.

Would come back for the Oysters, but the line may persuade me otherwise.
author: Jake R.

description: Love HH here!! Stopped by at 4:30pm on a Friday and got seated right away. Ordered oysters from their happy hour menu and the presentation came out beautiful. $1 oysters were so fresh and for their interior design left me wanting to stay longer. This is the prettiest oyster bar I've been to, they def set the standard.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
Amazing. 

Located in the finance district parking can be a challenge.
Raw oysters, tea leaf salad and Rosé is all you need to fall in love with this place.
author: Marlee B.

description:
Leo's is great. What a cute little spot!

We indulged again for a work lunch, and I loved it from the moment we walked in! They have a few different dining areas with a more traditional looking oyster bar in the front, and a cute little tiki room in the back with Lilly Pulitzer looking pillows, and wicker chairs and tables. 

No one was seemingly in an oyster mood which was a shame given the location, but we had some truffle fries to share and opted for more traditional entreés around the table. I think about half of us opted for the crab cake sandwich, there was a veggie order, and I went for the salad with ahi tuna because...well, I'm a sucker for tuna!

I loved my salad and I'm pretty sure everyone was pleased with their dishes as well since we all made the clean plate club that day! 

Dessert is also on point! We shared a sundae and some of their cookies. 

I'd love to come back for HH and some oysters another time!
author: Jessica M.

description:
Leo's Oyster Bar is a serious upgrade from the old Wexler's and I'm glad they are here. It's another amazing establishment from none other than the people that brought you: Marlowe, Park Tavern and The Cavalier. Seriously, what a line up of restaurants. 

I popped by a couple weeks ago to finally check out the space as I've been meaning to get in here for quite some time and it was beautiful. I'm pretty sure Ken Fulk did the design work at Leo's because most of the other restaurants I mentioned above have the same "feel". Leo's takes on a more tropical vibe from the 50's and it makes you want to order the classics. 

That being said, I ordered a Gibson martini and some of the pickled vegtables because that's how I roll. The cocktail was fantastic and the vegtables equally as good. I wasn't terribly hungry but, noticed my neighbors lobster roll (which looked heavenly) and the trays of beautiful oysters all over the restaurant. So, next time I will be getting those for sure :) 

Head here for classic cocktails and oysters, you won't be disappointed.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city for their food, restaurant aesthetic, and warm and accommodating staff.

Ask for Heather or Eric and the ever romantic Table No. 77 when you're making a reservation. 

Rosè, oysters, the top secret Marlowe fries, and their chocolate mousse are all to die for. 

Oh! And the Mad Men cocktail. Yum!

I could easily dine here twice a week (and sometimes I do)!
author: Tayler H.

description:
I'm pretty much a Leo's addict. Oysters, hamachi, lobster, cocktails... the list goes on. If I could eat ever meal here for the rest of my life, I'd be a happy girl (but also broke). This absolutely deserves 5 stars, but most of the items on the menu are overpriced. 

Anything you order on the menu will be outstanding, but I suggest asking your server for a variety of oysters to begin with. Order the hamachi next, and finish with the risotto or lobster roll. I highly recommend splitting with another person so you can taste more dishes!
author: Emmy Q.

description:
3-3.5 stars but rounding down since the prices are high for the quantity (it could have been just the couple items we ordered). Super cute spot in the FiDi to grab drinks/snacks at. My friend and I walked in before another event to check Leo's out, and we were able to grab two of the last remaining bar seats around 6pm on a Friday. It was definitely busy in the restaurant as well, so reservations are highly recommended to avoid any waiting. We tried:

-Chelsea Gems (Washington, $4.25/ea) & Oyster Eliose (Celery & Melon, $5/ea) [http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=dTeI9-EUmaLAJc1pALuOAg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]: We ordered 4 of the Chelsea's and 2 of the Eloise. I loved the size of the Chelsea's since they were Kumamoto sized, but they were a little too briny for my preference. I wouldn't get these again. However, the Eloise oysters were delicious, and I loved the combination of the celery and melon on it. Recommended!
-Foie Gras Toast (Ginger, Soy, Scallions, Uni Butter, $20, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3MSjiJJ_N7aCXOpXmVpqDQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Holy foie gras, I loved the creaminess of the foie, and the overall flavors. It was a tiny bit too salty for me, and overall this dish is super super rich, but it was worth trying once if you love foie and uni.

Drinks will run you around $12/each, which seems to be the average for the swankier bar/restaurants in the city. Service was very good, even at the bar, and they are really friendly there. Parking was surprisingly fairly easy to find since there are some metered spots on this street.
author: Amy D.

description:
I was expecting something special and it turned to be nothing but $$$$. My friend generously picked up the bill at the end so it's not even my $$$$ but I still felt that it was overpriced. 

It's one of the hot new restaurants in FIDI so make sure to make a reservation a week or more in advance.

We shared:
Golden Trout Roe Caviar Bites ($15 for 3 pieces)
Crab & Lobster Cake ($17)
Japanese Hamachi Crudo ($17)
Rock Shrimp Toast ($15)
Tuna Conserva Toast ($13)
Seafood Bisque ($19)
Fries with Dynamite Sauce ($7)

This was barely enough food for 2 not super hungry people. Did anything taste great? Not really. Everything was just ok and about 50%-100% more expensive than it should've been.

The decor is nice though. We sat in the back tiki lounge, which was more relaxed and quieter than the rest of the restaurant. Each room of the restaurant had a different vibe.
author: Yi Z.

description:
The space is not big but charming, and the bar looks great. We later found out that there's a lounge area and a tiki event space hidden at the back. We shared a few items between the two of us. We got two deviled eggs with a fried oyster on top. It was a delicious mix of textures, and I love fried oysters. We also got a couple of raw oysters, and it tasted very fresh. 

We got the tuna carpaccio with the tea leaf salad. It was also flavored with peanuts and garlic, and it was a wonderful combination of flavors. This was one of our favorite dishes. We also ordered the albacore dish. The citrus in this dish slightly overpowered the other items, and it was more strange to us though we still finished it. 

We also shared the lobster bisque and the mussels. We made sure to dip all the pieces of bread we had into both soup and sauce, and it was amazing. The lobster bisque was fresh and scrumptious with ample chunks of seafood. The mussels was clean and fresh, and the sauce was just right and perfect with both mussels and the bread. Overall the food and service here were great.
author: James K.

description:
Leo's Oyster Bar is one of those places that is so classy and well-designed that they could offer a subpar experience and I would still probably give a 5-star review. Stepping through the doors of Leo's is like stepping into a wonderland that's reminiscent of a retro Miami. I was truly blown away by the ambiance and decor of the bar, especially the incredible wallpaper and light fixtures. It really looks like they took immense care when designing and decorating the space. My friend and I met there around 5:30 for happy hour drinks, and were pleasantly surprised to find two open seats at the bar. 

I ordered the Garden Party cocktail (gin, egg white, and fresh herbs), and my friend got the Mah Jong (bourbon, raspberry, and tea). Both cocktails were delicious and beautifully presented. I absolutely loved the herbs and small, dried flowers in my drink. Since we knew we'd be there for longer than one drink, we ordered 6 oysters, Leo's deviled eggs, and the classic French fries with dynamite sauce. The oysters were super fresh, the deviled eggs were overflowing with fried oyster goodness, and the dynamite sauce was addictive. We ordered a second round, and I stayed with the Garden Party because it was so good. The bartenders were very attentive and friendly and we were never in need of anything. I can't wait to go back!!
author: Regina L.

description:
Such beautiful ambiance and great oysters but not a place to come for your full meal. I and 3 friends dined here last night for a friend's birthday dinner and we had a variety of things but the plates are all pretty tiny and come at a hefty price. To start we split 16 oysters with 4 different types and each was prepared and tasted so fresh. We sat in front of the shucker and were able to see the care and detail he put plating each oyster. Next, we had the following for our meal:
- 3 Leo's deviled egg with wing fried oyster ($6 per egg) and an Uni butter baked oyster. 5/5 on the deviled eggs - the wing sauce and crispy oyster paired nicely.  My friend wasn't a huge fan of the uni butter oyster. 
- Rock shrimp toast - 2/5. Bland taste and thought the toast could have been crispier
- Steak tartar - 4/5 - A Nice big dollop of Uni on top gave it an interesting kick. Enough for 3 people to split and have a couple bites. 
- Japanese hamachi - 4 single pieces, nice fish but nothing that blew me away - 3/5
- French fries - nice size portion and sauce was amazing - 5/5

For drinks, we started with a bottle of sparkling rose, 4 garden parties (so beautiful and tasty - you have to get), 4 espresso cocktails for dessert and also split their chocolate mouse. The chocolate mousse was so so tiny but like a thick brownie batter... so tasty but if you're in the mood for dessert, probably better to each get your own or at least only split with 2 people. Looking back, we had a lot of alcohol but not food and our bill came to $400 pre-tip. I'll probably be back for a cocktail and oysters during happy hour or after work, which will likely still amount to an expensive hh but will not be back for a full meal.
author: Aryn C.

description:
Ok, you've heard about, and have probably seen images of, the interior work, here at Leo's... go see it. The atmosphere is intoxicating and and thoroughly envelops you. 

I've had the pleasure of delivering some of their oysters for quite some time now, yet hadn't had the opportunity to dine with them until the week before last. The food only elevates the experience. I came here on a first date and while I can't say it overshadowed my glowing charm, it definitely set the stage for a wonderfully blooming relationship. We will be back again... and again. 

The menu is superb and reflects the care put into the design of the whole experience. I'll recommend any of the oyster preparations and appetizer choices; it depends only on your adventurousness. As far as main courses, we had the lobster roll w/ unit butter (drooly grins) and the steamer clams with sake broth (whoa!and yes!) I personally don't drink alcohol, but if the spicy ginger lime-ade with Thai chili is a representation of the care put into the cocktails, I'd say you can't go wrong.  

Go be here awhile. You won't regret it.
author: Evan C.

description:
In love with Leo's. The decor has an island vibe with a bit of Great Gatsby and the 50s. The wallpaper is already jumping up in Instagram posts. The details are down to the water cup. It's classy, it's fun and if you love Marlowe or Park Tavern as much as i do you'll enjoy your experience here. I made a prime time dinner reservation a few weeks back and arrived very excited . . .

I thoroughly enjoyed a couple beautiful Garden Party cocktails. Refreshing, delicious and seems to be one of their more popular drinks. Leo's Mai Tai came in a fun theme cup inspired by a Polynesian dancer. The Barbarita had a kick for a spicier palette. Liked the Deviled egg with fried oyster. I thought it was fried chicken! That's how good it was. For $6 a piece, glad it packed that much flavor. The tator tot with brandade and tapenade had good crunch for untraditional tots. I savored each piece of the Foie Gras Toast. Surprised by the soy sauce. As a native San Franciscan i've had a lot of Clam Chowder and this is one of the best i've had. I don't rank the Seafood Bisque as highly but i doubt it has the cream and butter the Clam Chowder has :) Salmon was perfectly cooked and the piccata sauce gave it a nice luxurious lemon sauce.

Service was not pretentious at all. They were extremely friendly and welcoming. We were well taken care of and the highlight was at the end of night when we asked if they had any mint, gum or similar candy. The restaurant didn't officially have any but they asked around and a staff member had some altoids which they placed on Leo's imprinted coaster over a glass plate. Best presentation i've ever seen for altoids.

We're not light eaters (or drinkers) so the bill grew very quickly. Probably better for date night as a large party may have a hard time maneuvering though i did get a sneak peek at the Hideaway bar area in the back if you do want a big group.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Dinner review. 

Salmon tartare marrow toast - 2/5
Leo's Louie Crab Shrimp - 3/5
Lobster roll + uni butter - 1/5
Short rib + uni butter - 4/5
Fries + dynamite sauce - 3/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
Came for the decor, was decently impressed with the food. I've been hearing about and seeing this place all over Instagram, and since my birthday was approaching, I figured it was worth a visit. I've frequented other restaurants in this group (Park Tavern, Cavalier, Marlowe), and am a fan of their intricate decor and well-thought out menus. Leo's is no different. Beautiful interior and unique, seasonal menu. Service was decent- our server wasn't really into recommending dishes and seemed overwhelmed by serving a group of 4 girls with lots of questions.

The dishes are definitely small, so if you come with the intention of sharing plates, be aware. That way you're not shocked when the crab cake comes out and is barely enough for 2 people. Or when your chocolate mousse dessert literally arrives in a shot glass, enough for 1 person. I will say that the cocktails are delicious and made with fresh herbs and ingredients. 

All in all, I'm glad I came and experienced, but it's not a place I will be dying to return to in the near future.
author: Lex M.

description: This place is so good. A little bit on the spendy side. But come on you're worth it. Good food,  great drinks, wonderful staff
author: Stephen S.

description:
I love all-things seafood and oysters and came here on the recommendation of Genevieve Y's yelp review. 

My gf Suany and I made girly date night plans here on Saturday night and were the first ones seated. We sat at at the bar and were pleasantly greeted by a cute girl with chic tats who took care of us all night with drink and food orders.

Upon entrance, I was anticipating a much larger dining room, based on the photos. However, the layout was chic and inviting regardless! The cool retro-Hawaiian wallpaper is only really dominant at the front part of the restaurant with a few tables. The main dining hall is composed of a gorgeous bar along with half a dozen or so white tables parallel to the bar.

Everything we had was delicious and beautifully presented. However, as many have noted, all the dishes here are really dainty and small. We were content at the end of the meal, but certainly could have eaten more. We ordered 3 diff types of Washington oysters  (3.50-5/each)- these were all so sweet and delicious. We also ordered the Salmon Tartare ($16), Foie Gras Toast, and Caviar ($21 for 4 little bites). At the end, we really enjoyed the Lemon dessert with crumbs - it was tart, light, and delish!

We ordered wine ($13-16/glass) and the Garden cocktail ($14) as well. I loved the Garden Cocktail- it was gorgeous but also tasted refreshing!

This spot is perfect for drinks & snacks, happy hour, a light dinner for a date night or close friends. The amazing food, drinks and pretty ambiance make it a fun spot! I look forward to returning for the Uni Toast next time.
author: Veronica S.

description: Loved the atmosphere and the really kind hostess! Food was good but the service was standout!
author: Sarah K.

description:
This place is easily my new favorite go to in the city. The food and drink menu are spectacular, the service is outstanding, and the quality of the food you get is fantastic. It's rare that you find a place where each dish is so thoughtfully created and for the employees to love their job so much that they'll tell you about it. Leo's is a rare new gem in this city of all too many disappointing one visit wonders restaurants.

The SO and I actually only came to Leo's for drinks around 10pm on a Friday night. When we got there, the place was packed. If you've never seen any photos of the place, the walls are pink with tree designs painted on. It's got a sort of tiki bar vibe, but also 1950s swanky classy oyster bar vibe that cater well to the clientele for this place -- mostly saw people that were a bit older dressed fairly well, so basically the FiDi crew. It's not particularly large, and is more conducive to smaller parties. It's basically split into bar seats and small table seats -- people at the bar definitely looked like they were going to bump elbows.

Fortunately for us, the waiter brought us to the back of the restaurant where they actually have a not so secret overflow room called The Hideaway. The Hideaway serves drinks and bar bites, which is exactly what we wanted. It was a fairly small room, same decor as outside, but the Sinatra playing in the background made the vibe perfect for date night. 

I got the Banana daiquiri and the SO got the mah johng, and the mad men. Most interesting thing about the daiquiri was that the texture of the drink was actually like the consistency of a typical mixed drink rather than a slushy like mixture. Each drink had a generous portion of alcohol, yet the contents of the drink worked really well together. 

For food, we got the salmon roe, smoked salmon on an everything chip, tuna toast, 2 Fanny Bay oysters, and a blood orange creamsicle. We loved the food. Everything was super thoughtfully created on their part -- the waitress told us about how the everything chip was meant to mimic an everything bagel. The oysters were also the freshest oysters I've ever had -- super meaty, but so fresh and rich in flavor and deliciousness. Each bar bite had a lot of small parts contributing to the dish, but unlike other restaurants, it was really apparent what each ingredient was doing on the plate. It didn't seem like it was there for visual garnish, it all improved the flavor experience.

The most outstanding part of the night was undoubtedly the service. It was evident that the waitresses were having a great time as they would often dance over to the table to chat with us, they were super super personable and fun to talk to and talked to us about the head chef's commitment to fresh, great oysters (they shuck them together as a staff and then if the quality if no up to par, send it back to the source). Most interesting, they told us about how much they loved their job and how they felt like their managers cared for them and cared for the quality of the food that they were putting out there. This effusive positive attitude is something I rarely see in other restaurants, and certainly an often overlooked component about what helps define one's experience at a restaurant.

I really can't tell you enough about how much I love this place. The final price for everything was high ($100 pre tip), but if you're willing to splurge a little for the quality and the experience, I think it's completely worth it. There are a million other money-suck restaurants in this city, but Leo's is certainly not in that crowd.

tldr; probably my favorite new restaurant in SF right now; delicious food and drinks, great service! excellent place for a date night and probably smaller groups
author: Jasmine X.

description: Great little spot in the FIDI for some oysters.  Got a good variety of it and a lot of it tasted pretty good.  Has a really chill ambiance type of vibe and the staffs are really attentive! This place is a bit on the pricier side however, but we still definitely enjoyed the oysters.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Side of pickled veggies
One dozen oysters
Raw hamachi on grilled avocado
Rock shrimp toast
Seafood bisque
Crab cake
Lobster roll

We liked everything. The oysters were great. Our favorite was the lobster roll but what we would order again, and again, is the rock shrimp,toast

I'd skip the crab cake, a bit fishy.

I think the waiter was trying to be nice to make sure we all had food but he brought it all at the same time.   We told him we were sharing. There was barely enough room on the table for all the food when it's all brought at once. It was very awkward.    

They should have paced it better.   We were done in about 30 minutes and it felt like they were rushing us.

So be sure to tell them...can we have the soup first, then bring the toast, and then the hamachi, then bring out the lobster roll last...

It's a cool,space but very loud and you sit very close to other diners. I spent a lot of time saying WHAT DID YOU SAY?
author: Foodlover B.

description: Great drinks to choose from and lovely environment. Some of the food choices however, were very poor plain and not as flavorful. I highly recommend the devil eggs and oyster, but not the other three grilled oyster options (3). The clams and octopus dish was not amazing and thought if would be, but could of used extra love because I love octopus (seafood in general). Wished for a better food and drink experience.
author: Lola M.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday February 4, 2016 @ 6pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Battery Members & FiDi Professionals- Gents in Pastel Checkered Shirts & Ladies in LBD's w/ High Boots & Chanel 2.55 Classic Bags 
Music:  Jazz; Coltrane, Ella Fitzgerald
Decor:  Preppy at It's Finest.  Pretty Candle-Lit Conservatory, Pastel Painted Walls, Floral WallPaper, Long Bar Parallel to Banquette Seating Makes for a Fun & Lively Dining Experience
Service:  Very Chatty Females Though the Men were On-Point
Devour:  Deviled Egg w/ Wing Fried Oyster, Oyster Carbonara, Sea Urchin on Toast Points, Osetra Caviar Creme Fraiche and Truffle, Bottarga Tuna Conserva Nicoise, Mussels & Frites.  For Dessert:  Lemon Mousse + Brown Butter Streusel + Cookie
Total:  $155.30
Brought to You By The People of Marlowe, Park Tavern & Cavalier
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Wonderful ambience & setting. We had a group of 4 for lunch- tea leaf salads, oysters, French fries. Service was excellent- fast, friendly. Love that the restaurant is literally right around the corner from our office.

I personally love this restaurant group which also owns The Cavalier, Marlowe, Park Tavern.
author: Al G.

description:
Overall: Dined at Leo's for Happy Hour. Love this tucked away spot for its cool ambiance, delicious oysters and cocktails.

Food: 5 stars. Love the oyster selection. While they didn't have my favorite Kusshi oysters that day, the server recommended the St. Simone which I loved just as much. The seafood bisque was delcious.

Drinks & Service: 5 stars. Staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. Loved the way the bartender made one of my favorite drinks.

Space 4-5 stars: Its really beautiful and I love the the warm feel they've done with the lights and arrangement. However, it is really narrow space so come early to grab a seat at the bar.

I definitely want to visit Leo's again.
author: Jessica C.

description:
5 stars for drinks, oysters, and the environment. It is worth a visit to Leo's for the ambiance and decor. They have a few rooms, and it's fun to see them all. The staff is really great and they go out of their way to make sure you are enjoying yourself.

3 stars for the food. We came for dinner and ordered the Leo's Louie, which was expensive and pretty disappointing. The lobster roll, which I was really looking forward to, also did not meet expectations. The clam chowder was pretty good though. 

All in all, great for happy hour and pictures!
author: Lauren A.

description:
Apparently, this is one of the most beautiful restaurants in San Francisco. It has a nice tropical theme with a good soundtrack playing in the background. The service was good and friendly - my glass was always filled with water!

The food was a bit overpriced and underwhelming. 

+ mussels - wasn't stand out; the andouille was a nice touch 
+/- devil's egg - I never understand why you only get half an egg per order...that's a whole other issue. In any case, the filling was quite yummy, the egg was nicely cooked, but is all as expected for half an egg at $6.
+/- leo's louie with gem lettuce (combo) - a good portion of crab and shrimp; a bit too lemony 
+/- lobster roll - wasn't stand out; the fries were overly salty
author: Margaret R.

description:
Pricey, but fancy. For two, you'll walk into this place, in awe over the multi million dollar interior, fashioned in retro glam days' ways, down to the very last gilded lamp. 

The oysters are great, the other food is good. They tried really hard to get the aesthetic as authentic as possible, almost too hard.

Very nice- but that price!!! Whew...
author: Brianna S.

description: Overall great meal. Split between the two of us, we got the Butterfish, tater tots, and the short rib. Short rib was definitely the highlight, full of flavour and fell off the bone. Wouldn't recommend the butterfish - it's served with white toast that really killed the flavour of the dish. Service was spectacular, we were visiting the city and our waitress wrote us a huge in depth list of places to go for drinks. Only complaint was that the restaurant was very chilly (where half of the guests were wearing their jackets).
author: Josie M.

description:
Really cool and swanky place- they serve fancy cocktails and oysters after work. People were dressed up pretty nice. Our party was in a back room that was hidden- reminded me a little bit of a speakeasy! 

Although the cocktails are pricy, they are delicious! Definitely worth checking out with a friend after work. Would also be perfect for a date.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Don't get the Foie Gras- it's more like "foie ugh"

Deviled eggs  

Skinny dip  cocktail was good.

Clam chowder was a safe choice but Boudin still wins the battle.

Lobster roll was good, my friend said.

EXPENSIVE! Coz the interior is good i guess. Service is also great. So maybe 3.5 stars.
author: Keet K.

description: Great place for fresh oysters and seafood. Went early with a friend so didn't have any problems getting a seat at the oyster bar. Service was fast and attentive. Tried 4 different kinds of oysters, soup, tea leaf salad, bone marrow, and fries. Oysters were fresh and delicious. The soup was good but a bit heavy. I didn't love the tea leaf salad as much as other places in the city. Wouldn't recommend. The bone marrow was great. Definitely get the deviled eggs. Was my favorite after the oysters! It lives up to everyone's reviews of them. A bit pricy but a must try in the city at least once.
author: Emily F.

description: This place. So good. Expensive AF but for the ambiance, service and INSANE seafood it's worth it. Cocktails are great too. Such a nice place for a special occasion!
author: Alice U.

description:
New favorite restaurant in SF!  Superb service with a really cool vibe that is chic, modern but also rustic.  If you are passionate about excellent quality seafood, oysters and vino -- Leo's doesn't disappoint.  

The deviled eggs are ridiculous!  So too is the lobster roll!

Fantastic lunch and/or dinner destination.
author: Duryea R.

description:
Leo Oyster Bar is DEEEELICIOUS!! It just opened couple weeks ago and this place gets packed. I would suggest to either sit at the bar or call in for a reservation. I did a walk-in and was able to get a seat at the bar. The bartenders/servers are awesome and super friendly. 

All the dishes I ordered were on point. The oysters are fresh and they have different types of oysters from different states. The portions are kinda like tapas sized  - so it's good for sharing and you'll be able to try different dishes. 

What I ordered: 
- Salmon Tartare, Marrow, Capers and Dill (Toast) 
- All the oysters on the menu (total 7 different types)
- Crab and Lobster Cake, Cucumber, and Horseradish 
- Mussels en Papilote, Tomato, Pancetta, Olive and Chili
- Pan Seared Salmon, Caramelized Fennel, Radicchio and Piccata Sauce
author: Jenn L.

description: Went there last night (Aug 10.2018) with a couple friends, we ordered 3 appetizers and 3 entrees and 2 desserts, waitress was nice, but honestly no personality, it's business, during our meal from the beginning to the end, she was so eager to clean our tables, even though there are still food on the plate, food was good enough, the place was very nice and charming, good atmosphere, would be nice to get that from the employees as well.
author: Paul M.

description: This place used to be fantastic and now it's just mediocre. Cute decor but the back dining room smells like the adjoining bathrooms. Food was okay, we found the lobster to be mealy and the special oysters to be not so special. The restaurant cleverly disguised our forgotten bisque as simply the last dish to come out which made for a kind of fragmented meal. All in all, this place has gone down stream since it opened.
author: Caroline M.

description: Love this place. Walking into each beautifully decorated room feels like falling down the rabbit hole. The food and cocktails did not disappoint.  Wonderfully fresh seafood and inspired libations, plus a great bar scene, make this one not to be missed.
author: Ashley F.

description:
I'm from the East Coast, where "oyster bar" has certain connotations. Yes, Leo's has an extensive oyster list, but I was disappointed it wasn't the real deal.

Very cute place...loved the wallpaper...that has more of a cocktail versus oyster bar vibe. Ordered a dozen of the raw Humboldt oysters (thought I couldn't go wrong with the only (?) local oyster on the menu) and disliked them: fatty and tasteless, not briny at all. The hamachi crudo...3 slices of hamachi and two teeny slices of dried avocado for $17, really?...was also tasteless. The salmon roe appetizer...three tiny puff pastry cups with salmon and roe, $18...at that point we were just DONE and didn't stay for entrees. 

I rarely complain about prices, but in this case, they really were excessive. The bill for those three dishes and the corking fee for our wine was $150. Go to Hog Island, which is not far from Leo's, they know what they're doing and you won't be disappointed.
author: Elisa C.

description:
When you're in the financial district and you have that expense account at your beck & call then Leo's is the perfect place to spend that dough.

Their raw bar menu consist of bivalves from both the East Coast as well as the West Coast - (psst, THEY HAVE CHERRYSTONE CLAMS!), along with king crab, lobsters and caviar (only menu available during happy hour I might add)! I tried The Mad Man cocktail made with rye, benedictine & citrus, perfect HH cocktail and you can't stop at just 1 -go on and try; I double dog dare you-.

When you do get your fluky hands on the food menu then order the deviled eggs with fried oyster (best in town); I can just keep stuffing those suckers in my face. The sea urchin toasts was a salty creamy fantasy and that tea leaf salad with Ahi Tuna and charred avocado (all extra $$ of course) would put a Burmese restaurant to shame.

Also, skip the Lobster roll as the brioche gets greasy and go for the Lobster and Crab cakes instead and while we're luxuriously prancing around all over the menu, dodge them baked oysters as well because if it ain't raw (or sometimes deep fried) then "it ain't worth the whiskey";*hiccup*..
author: Lo-an L.

description:
This place is said to be the most Instagrammed restaurant in San Francisco and I can see why. The eclectic decor just beckons you to start taking pictures from the moment you enter. 
Paired with great food and service makes Leo's a fun spot to hang out with friends. 
Great selection of Oysters!!
author: Sam S.

description: I'm not sure why the ratings are so high here. Perhaps dinner is better? Came here for lunch and some of the items I wanted to order are only available for dinner (like the foie gras toast). The raw oysters were all good although pricey. The cooked ones weren't that great. I had the lobster roll which was ok but nothing special. The bread to lobster ratio was not to my liking...way too much bread. Same with the other sandwiches. The fries were pretty tasty. Service was good. The restaurant itself has an interesting layout. Looks like the inside of a former salon possibly. The front of the restaurant has a long bar and lots of small tables. It looks like the back part of the restaurant can accommodate larger tables.
author: Musetta S.

description:
Amazing Amazing Amazing
We started with the hot oysters and migrated into the raw.  Must haves are bisque diamonds and pearls and fresh oysters. Service is better than home.
author: Reed C.

description:
I am so so so thrilled we found this place -- it's amazing.  Being from New England, I am known to be a seafood snob, and I'm usually never impressed...but oh...my..god...this place is phenomenal.

We started off each with a raw oyster, and these were great -- highly recommend.  Great presentation, great taste. We then each got a "Leo's Deviled Egg with Wing Fried Oyster," these were great as well.    We tried the "Osetra, Creme Fraiche an Truffled Beet Pancake" -- which everyone went crazy for.  These are so rich and flavorful, a must try -- like seriously, you have to get these.  Also, do try the "Sea Urchin, Ginger, Soy, and Scallion Toast" -- seriously so flavorful and rich -- melts in your mouth (we all loved these too).  

The "House-Made Tater Tot, Brandade and Tapenade" is also a good pic -- but FYI they aren't your average tater tots.  There are like five huge pieces of tots, and they kind of taste like hash browns...but like REALLY GOOD hash browns.  The french fries were french fries, so they were good (nothing crazy).  

Okay I have to end this with the things I did NOT like.  Honestly, the clam chowder...was NOT good.  Like I said, I'm from New England, so I take my chowder very seriously.  I did not like the consistency and the bacon in it/the flavor.  I would not recommend (no one else liked it either).  Also, the mussels...."Mussels en Papillote, Tomato, Pancetta, Olive, and Chili" -- I'm sorry I did not like it at all.  They just tasted so strange, not good at all -- and I LOVE mussels, I've never had one I didn't like...until last night. (and again, the group felt the same way)

Oh and dessert..we got the chocolate mousse and the strawberry sunday -- both bomb.  Definitely recommend both of them, but will say the chocolate mousse comes in a pineapple shaped dish...soooo it's so Instagram worthy. (lol)

Okay overall, definitely my favorite restaurant in San Francisco right now -- and I highly recommend.  The decor is phenomenal -- its like chic havana style.  The music was this awesome salsa playlist, which I loved.  We sat in "the hideaway" in the back -- and ummmmmmmmm it was great.  I only want to sit back there in the future.  It's decorated so well and it is very intimate.  I'm in love with Leo's.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Once in a while these days, I like to go and grab dinner by myself at nice places. I decided to try out this place myself since my friends either don't want to spend too much money or they don't like seafood. Anyways, I decided to come by and grab a drink and get some food. 

I started off with drinks - something fruity and delicious. I don't actually remember the drink's name, but I remember it had flowers and some sparkling wine. The food I ordered was delicious. I started off with oysters - 3 different types - Grassy Bar, Hog Island, and Irish Point. They were all good, but I think my favorite was the Hog Island. Definitely a great oyster. 

I then got the dish off of the 7x7 listing - Leo's cobb. I decided to go with a combination of crab and shrimp instead of one or the other. It was beautifully plated and really good, but it was just not enough food. I next decided to go with a toast point. Mine came with crab. 

Since I was by myself, I decided to go with sitting at the bar. It was a great place to enjoy some food and drinks. I got there around 7 and it wasn't too hard to find a spot at the bar, but honestly, by the time it was about 7:45/8, the place got packed with people. The mood lighting being red was a bit weird, but I did love the atmosphere overall. 

Protip: fresh oysters!
author: Nina Y.

description: I looove the ambiance in this restaurant! Walked in on a Friday at noonish and was able to grab a table for 4. As first timers we ordered the clam chowder, seafood bisque , Salmon/shrimp/scallop burger, louie salad. Oysters were fantastic of course. Great food! And not to mention, a REALLY good old fashioned! I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Sarina A.

description:
Back several months ago, a former Yelp elite Genevieve Y. (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=_aSs5dSAabuwnXUGBPzASw) posted a five star review (still not sure why she isn't still elite.  If you know her reviews, you'll know that it's all about details with her.
About a month ago, my visit here was for a lunch meeting here.  Arriving around 12:30 pm with reservations, the restaurant was crowded, both at the bar and dining area.  We were seated at the second table from the door so I didn't get much chance to see the rest of the restaurant.  Most of the tables that line the front are two or four toppers while the bar sits to the left.  The walkways are narrow so beware if you are claustrophobic.  After some brief discussion about the menu, we gave our waiter our orders.
We shared two small bites or snacks, the assorted housemade pickles and smoked trout dip, trout roe, and chips; great conversation while munching on this, using fingers and toothpicks to try the different things.  For my main meal, I ordered Leo's Louie combination (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=HscW7e73Amn83Cji7-QHNw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), which featured rock shrimp and King crab meat.  For $22.00, the seafood portion is generous and liked that all of the ingredients were segregated so nothing got soggy.  
Normally, I would eat something more substantial, but both of my lunch companions were in a health conscious mood, prompting my nutritious choice.  It was actually filling enough for me.  Service was decent and not particularly memorable as glasses were filled and empty plates removed.  
Yes, I would like to return and, judgining by Cherylynn N.'s (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg) dinner experience, lunch is probably the better choice.
author: Mike C.

description: Service was flawless. Oysters fresh and tasty. Bisque was alright. Bone Marrow was lovely. Cocktails were plenty. Did i mention the service and the ambiance? Lots of romantic lighting and amazing seating. It's a gem!
author: Mary N.

description: Best oyster. Very-good seafood restaurant in town .atmosohere is great. Menu choices are wide with variety of seafood. Fresh and yummy will be back
author: Ceseline D.

description:
The oysters are wonderful, fresh and simply delicious. 

The wine was lovely and our server was great. 

The mussels were the worst I've ever had; small, dry, fishy, not fresh. We sent them back. (And I never do this, I usually grin and bear it). Just bad. 

The mushroom, goat cheese toast points had literally no goat cheese and tasted worse than cheap, out-of-the-box frozen apps from smart and final. Horrible. The portion was extremely small and it cost sixteen dollars. Fail. 


Now the seating. They sat us at one of two tables in front of the host station; yes, IN FRONT of the hostess station by front door. Literally situated were patrons wait for their 'real' table. This is seriously the most awkward place I've ever sat in a restaurant, not to mention an expensive one. Your view at this table: a coat closet, utensil / napkin stand, hostess station and people checking in to their table all night long. The table is set away from the main restaurant. I felt like we needed a dunce hat and were scorned to the detention corner.  For how pricey this spot is, this is unacceptable. They have got to get rid of this table. 

There are too many great spots in town to get oysters. I would definitely pass on this spot. Not worth it whatsoever.
author: Brooke S.

description:
I frequent SF often, and this is my favorite spot. The oysters are amazing, service and staff are great too. I usually go one of each oyster and they are excellent in taste and texture. The price is a little on the higher side, but quality is definitely there. 

Only thing I would recommend to mgmt is a more extensive red wine selection.
author: Milad S.

description:
It's a 3.3/5

The Great:
Ambiance. So super cool and different, even the bathrooms
Service is A+ so sweet and accommodating
Oysters
Cocktails yasssss

The Not So Great
Noise - I like my energetic noise bumpin vibe but it's a shouting match
Food is a big womppppp. Went for dinner and was not blown away by anything other than oysters
Back area is so dark you can barely see each other. Can't see the menu at all. Can't take pictures (where's the food porn??)
Uncomfortable seating

So 3.3/5 is for dinner.  BUT it's a 4.5/5 for a cocktails and oyster only bar. Will re-review when I try it for that!
author: Marie M.

description: The ambient lighting, decor, cocktails, food, and service was all great! We lucked out and was able to sneak in a light meal before my husband's holiday party in December.
author: Bella B.

description:
Maybe the cutest restaurant that I've ever stepped foot in. This is the sort of place that takes you out of the depressing fog of San Francisco and makes you want to order a glass of rosé, sit back and enjoy! Banana leaf wall paper is lined with mirrors, huge funky lights and a gorgeous long, well-lit bar.

We ordered the tea leaf salad and added charred avocado. There is also the option to add tuna carpaccio which I highly recommend. 

Lobster roll was good but I prefer a hot lobster roll.  This one was served New England style with uni butter. I did not even notice the uni butter but the lobster was tender and flavorful. The brioche was spot on and the fries were solid.
 
The hot oyster with seaweed was way too salty. I'd skip the hot oysters next time. I will absolutely come back the next time I am in SF for dinner, and enjoy a glass of rosé or a cocktail.
author: Brittany F.

description:
This was my second visit here, and it will be my last.
This meal was a big expensive letdown from my first meal here 6 months earlier.
Both the service and food were off.
Service was inconsistent, had slight attitude at times like they were doing me a favor to order me a $15 cocktail.  Other times the staff were slightly aloof or unprofessional.
Ordered oysters, crab legs, and lobster claws from the raw seafood bar.
The $26 lobster claws (2) were overcooked and tough.
The lobster bisque was lukewarm.
Total came out to $150 for lunch 1-person.
For that price I expected better.
author: Marcus A.

description:
i expected THE WORLD of leo's oyster bar.  i think that was the downfall though, because when you go in with such expectations, things generally fall a little flat.  we showed up for dins at 8 pm on a monday without a ressie, there was a table available by the door, and a few seats at the bar, so walking in is definitely an option if you cant score a reservation.  this place books up super quickly.  we order cocktails right away, but it takes a long time for them to arrive. the drinks are beautifully made and presented,  the island time, with mezcal, is delicious. my gf really enjoyed the mai tai, which comes in a cute tiki glass. the garden party is really pretty!

for eats, we ordered so many things - 2x the deviled egg with wing fried oyster, smoked trout dip, house made tater tot, rock shrimp toast, foie gras, ahi tuna carpaccio, and hamachi. oh, and six different oysters.  it was a lot of food, but the portions are small and all the items are light.  the deviled egg arrived first, and that was probably the beginning of leo's downfall, because when you open with such a FANTASTIC bite, you expect everything that follows to be just as good, but they are not, so it's doomed!  everything else was just okay, with the exception of the rock shrimp toast, which came out on kinda soggy bread and tasted like nothing.  meeps. 

3 rounds of cocktails for us with the above items, and the bill was just under 400 after tax and tip. so it's not cheap. lol, i would probably come back for the drinks but i feel that the food is sub-par for the prices they charge. atmosphere is great, service is a little eh.
author: Christina L.

description: This place is fabulous! Great Gatsby meets the 1950s with a tropical twist- as mentioned by a fellow Yelper. It's an Instagram moment the second you step foot inside this place. From the menu to the wallpaper and down to the water pitchers, no detail is overlooked. Thankfully this place is more than just about the atmosphere. The service was super attentive and the food was great. The tea leaf salad is a must! Our server highly recommended it and boy was he right. So much bright flavor in that dish. Do add the charred avocado- it's worth it. Or add both the charred avocado and tuna carpaccio. It's delicious. The lobster roll is delightful and if you're not starving- split the roll and the tea leaf salad with a buddy and round out your order with a glass of Rosé. I'll definitely return to Leo's.
author: Isabella J.

description: Still the best oysters I have EVER had in my life. Period. Yelp isn't letting me post a short review so I'm going to add a couple more words to this in order for my message to be heard by the masses.
author: Olya S.

description: Came into town for some errands and just searched for a seafood place for lunch. Turned out to be a great place. Large selection of fresh oysters and many other dishes. We had oysters of course, then two appetizers - Lobster bisque and the smoked tuna dip. Both were excellent. We sat at the bar as it was peak hour and we had no reservation but that was a pleasant experience overall. The bar staff was attentive and highly professional.
author: Ranny H.

description: I love the food here and have only been here for dinner, but in December I came here for lunch to have an early x mas celebration with my friend. In the beginning it started off really good-friendly waitress and they even split our food up since we were sharing. Got our first 2 apps then after 45 minutes the tuna tea leaf salad and lobster roll still didn't come out. I asked our waitress a few times and she said soon, or 5 minutes. No apology or any explanation. She would avoid my area and I had to go find her to ask her what's taking so long. She was snappy back at me saying it's coming. It's been an hour....If the kitchen is backed up or you forgot to put in the rest of the order then own up to it. I think waiting an hour for the rest of our food to come without explanation is unacceptable and for you to give me attitude is wrong. The tuna salad finally came and it was super acidic. When the lobster roll came I had to take it to go. I only have an hour lunch and I was gone for an hour and a half already. I couldn't even complain to the manager. Xmas lunch ruined and I haven't been back since. I really like their food, but it went downhill with that and service. Sucks....also this place is pricey so to be treated this way was just annoying and so disappointing.
author: Karen H.

description: The devil eggs are to die for!!!!!! They're amazing - like seriously... talk about the place, super cute and great place. ask for heather she so nice. We even had a chocolate mousse with a golden flake
author: Karina C.

description:
Great 70's vibe done in the most tasteful way possible (i.e. No plastic liners, fabrics, gaudiness). 

Our waiter was WONDERFUL and walked us through the complete menu - how large everything is, brine level, everything you could want to know about not only the oysters but entire menu. 

The deviled egg with fried oyster on top has this amazing sriacha aioli and all the textures blend together and make this crazy mouth explosion. I could've easily eaten a dozen. The oysters were perfect, and my extra dirty martini paired very nicely. 

The lobster roll and fries was great to fill us up (split 3 ways) and had "dynamite sauce" for fry dipping - more sriacha goodness. The lobster was large clumps and very fresh, not too mayonnaise-y. 

Also, not one but TWO hidden bars in the back. Don't stop at the first door :)
author: Megan M.

description:
LOVE Leo's Oyster Bar! A new official "must-go-there" for all my future trips to SF. The decor, atmosphere, service and food is a 5/5. 

My date and I came during the lunch (ends at 3pm)  and dinner (starts at 5:30pm) break but there is still a limited bar/snacks menu available. We sipped on a few specialty cocktails and snacked on fresh oysters and shrimp. It was perfect. 

I hands down adore the 1930s-esque urban retreat vibe and the staff makes it more wonderful. It is listed as $$$ so like any other luxury, prepare to splurge on yourself - but if you love good, quality food, it's totally worth it at Leo's.
author: Cherish K.

description: My wife and I really enjoy this restaurant: great service, cocktails and seafood. We've been here a few times and it's been consistently great across the board!
author: brett a.

description:
Walking by Sacramento street we decided to try this place.  The ambiance is great.  Lots of people inside we thought... Hmmm happy hour crowd?  Not really.  

I am not biased it's just the fact that I will provide. We looked at the menu and also checked yelp for recommendation.  I have to say Yelp and Yelper's...disappointed me with this one.  So,  here goes.

Atmorsphere = 4 stars 
For the $$$ Tables are tiny and everyone is in close quarters = 2 stars
Service (Joseph) =5 stars
Kitchen (very slow) = 2 start (Joseph had to apologize, 0the kitchen is backed up) 
Drinks had the Garden cocktail drink = 5 stars
Toast with Foie Gras and buttered Uni = 2 stars (vs Monseiur Benjamin) 
Deviled egg with fried oysters = 3 stars (vs Aquitaine) 
Baked Oyster Carbonara = 2 stars (vs Hog Island ) 
Seafood bisque = 5 stars (this is a homerun) 
Mussels en papillon = 3 stars (vs Plouf) 

Bottom line: 3.5 Stars - We were disappointed.  
This place is a shi shi.. foofoo. Service is excellent,  the food is OK with the exception of seafood bisque (homerun) and cocktail is awesome.  With that said it is overpriced.
author: SFoodie P.

description: SUPER expensive but it's really really cool inside. Be sure to have a reservation though. If you don't you will not have a table and you better hope there are a few spaces that are together at the bar. Great cocktails and food, but be ready to drop some cash on lunch. Love the decor!
author: Jessica B.

description:
NIBBLES AND BITS

Celebrated a friend's birthday here 2 weeks ago. The place was packed and fortunately they have a back lounge area for walk ins. It reminded me of a Tiki bar - not all of the umbrellas and candles, but a smaller space with actually more room than the main dining room.

The front room is long and narrow with tables on the right side - fairly close to each other a small space then the bar patrons - and there was no seat available in the place by the time we got there on a Friday night at 730pm. And there shouldn't be. I'm a big guy so getting back to this area in the tiny path between the tables on the right and the people at the bar was not fun, but that's my problem not there's.

It's a weird little menu - very small print - Bring those Readers!!
We started with a selection of the West Coast Oysters and a 'Raw Bay Scallop' in it's shell. The manager recommended it and it was very small but quite tasty. I highly recommend trying it - apparently it's a Thing now - to eat raw scallops. I'm so out of it. 

Bob had the Salmon - excellent $27.00 and I had the Lobster Roll for $32.00 - it was okay. It was good but they made up for the lack of Lobster by it being more like a Lobster slaw which does Not bring the Lobster flavor I'm looking for for $32 Bucks. The large plates also known as Dinner in my world - there are only 4 to choose from. I guess this is for nibblers. There's a Short Rib meal, Mussels (which are more appetizer to me), Salmon, & the Lobster Roll. They have a nice wine list. Decidedly this is more of a small plates / after work hors d'oeuvres hour. 

Also the service was excellent, and even though the tables were smaller in the back lounge I liked it more - more space, not as loud, attentive service.
author: Rew C.

description:
I went to Leo's Oyster Bar alone for lunch and the waitress was so amazing. I ordered the rock shrimp bacon sandwich and it came in like a light mix salad form on toasted white bread. 

Before my meal, my wonderful waitress gave me a bite of the seasoned chip with tuna. As my meal arrived, my waitress also comp'd me a glass of rose to accompany my sandwich and fries. Truly impressive and made me feel so welcome! Side note: there is no service in the room in the back, at least not for me. 

It's located next to Wayfare Tavern and definitely adheres to that old classic ambiance with a beautiful Palm Springs-y entrance that takes you back in time. 

Four stars for the high prices. I'd definitely go back for a happy hour but I'm not convinced this is somewhere that I need to go for the food.
author: Christine Y.

description:
Initially came for the dessert to celebrate my birthday, then happily stayed for oysters and caviar. All of which I highly suggest!! The oysters were large and fresh. The dessert rich and perfectly proportioned. And the caviar... Worth it. 

I felt so special wine'ing and dining at Leo's- the server was knowledgeable on the menu and so engaging; the decor took me to a Cuba'esque tropical escape from the busy city; and the food was so good I wish I had budgeted for a whole meal.

Perfect intimate birthday celebration spot, or date spot.
author: Regina D.

description:
Delightful little restaurant in the financial district. You will certainly need to like seafood and ideally raw food to be able to appreciate most of the menu. 

Raw bar has about 6-10 varieties of oysters from around the States, along with a few other seafood options. Can't go wrong if you like raw oysters. 

Highly recommend: deviled eggs with fried oysters. Also the toasts are great- fois gras in particular. 

Desserts are fine but not mind-blowing. 

Great service. Small restaurant but lively and cute.
author: Nikki S.

description:
The best oyster I've ever had in my life. No words. 

We did ended up trying the other food, everything was amazing. The decor was very cute and service was so friendly! It is on the pricer side but well worth it.
author: Tina O.

description:
Every year we have a restaurant with which we become obsessed. It even gets a mention in our holiday letters. This year, it's looking like that restaurant is Leo's Oyster Bar. We've been 3x the past few weeks and have tried nearly everything on the menu. 
TL;DR EVERYTHING IS FANTASTIC. You can hardly go wrong. 

* Raw bar: My new favorite in the city. Nice oyster selection, "fancy oysters" with pickled tomatoes and horseradish, prawns, raw clams, and the most delicious king crab legs perfected with the dynamite sauce (kewpie mayo, sriracha, and tobiko). Everything is so cold and fresh! I saw the picked king crab and was pleased we chose the legs. Very satisfying. 

* Caviar: loved the American sturgeon platter and all of the bites. Every single one. Seriously. Get the bites. 

* Small plates: The "tater tot" is like a latke topped with smoked fish & olive tapenade - highly recommend. The crab and lobster cake is good, but not as much of a wow as other items. Still recommend it! The fries are dangerously good - very salty and come with that addictive dynamite sauce. They also come with the lobster roll.

* Toasts: My favorite toast is the mustardy, buttery salmon tartar. Also enjoyed the tuna conserva and rock shrimp toasts. My companions loved the foie gras, if that's your thing. 

* Soups: The clam chowder is like liquid velvet - one of the best I've ever had, top 2 or 3 of my life. The rock shrimp bisque is silky, tarragon-y, and my husband's favorite recent discovery. Highly recommend each.

* Salad: The louis is an elegant salad for one, but the only item not optimized for sharing. For sharing, have crab legs from the raw bar or rock shrimp toast instead. 

* Crudos: My favorite is the scallop and jalapeño - such flavors and texture. The hamachi on grilled avocado melts in your mouth, the olive oil and flaky salt finish it expertly. The salmon carpaccio is very good and the favorite item of one of my companions, but the other two are truly divine in my eyes.  

* Large Plates: They will slice the lobster roll for easy sharing for up to four. It's good. Not the best lobster roll I've ever had, but maybe the best currently the city? A good amount of lobster, but not the massive mound one might hope for. I've already mentioned the dangerous fries. The mussels are plump and juicy. I think they are better shared so you can enjoy more items. The beef short rib with bordelaise sauce/potato puree/uni butter - that sauce! the meat you could cut with a spoon! What a fantastic meat dish at a seafood restaurant! I watched someone thoroughly enjoy the salmon, but didn't get a chance to try it yet myself. 

* Cocktails/wine: Good enough to come just for drinks. Won't be surprised if it starts making lists for the bar alone. Excellent wine list. Of the cocktails, I found the Island Girl too sweet, but someone who likes sweet happily downed it for me. Other than that, they've been perfect. The Mai Tai has been a favorite with everyone we've brought and comes in a delightful mug. It doesn't get smoother and classier than the Office Supplies. The Mah Jong is great. The Grasshopper has modernized the classic - real mint and no green coloring. My personal favorites have been the Garden Party - so fragrant! - and the ultra refreshing Babarita. 

* Dessert: I've been too full to partake, but watched friends enjoy the strawberry sundae once. 

* Decor: My house needs to be this exact kitschy, midcentury fantasy. 

* Service: Top notch. Couldn't be better. Bravo. 

* Con: Very loud. Haven't sat in the walk-in only room in the back where they serve everything except the large plates, yet. It looks lovely and I hold out hope it's quieter.
author: Veronica L.

description: Don't get me wrong, Leo's was good. Service was great, food was ok, ambiance was "hipster," but honestly, everything was just waaaaay overpriced. $13 minimum for a cocktail or a glass of wine...? Really? We had the mushroom toast, oysters (12), a salad and two drinks each between three people and it was close to $300. I had a good experience, but I think i could have had the same experience for less than $200 a person...
author: Lauren T.

description:
Oyster was fresh and the waiter was knowledgeable on which ones we would like.

Skip the king crab. They give you so little for $14.

A few mussels were closed so was disappointed by that. Also had the mushroom toast (liked it) and lobster roll (eh had better). Overall not a memorable dinner. Won't be going back.
author: Dana C.

description:
Loved everything about this place. We found it in Instagram because who doesn't decide they are going to eat at a place on Instagram? 

Sat at the bar because reserves were completely full. That was better anyway. One of the bartenders was a cool guy. Quick with cocktail suggestions (get the one with gin and egg whites was insane), also to call people "friend", mean that in best possible way... Great dude. 

The oysters were fantastic and there are several east and west coast options. Stick with west obviously fresher and better. 

Seems like it could be a good date spot. Tons of finance folks sitting at the bar and that's not a bad thing either just the type of crowd. Martinis were consumed and why not?
author: Josh M.

description: Casandra was truly amazing. I am a vodka girl, so I asked for a vodka cocktail with oysters that would pair best. Casandra prepared us an amazing drink with pineapple palms that tasted amazing with kuushii oysters. Ask for her every time you enter this oyster bar.
author: Jessica P.

description: Wonderful swanky atmosphere with a pleasant wait staff from the host to the oyster chef. The oysters is what gives this place its charm. They were perfectly shucked with not a grain of shell and well separated. For lunch the food options and actual sandwiches are quite underwhelming. The shrimp sandwich was so dry and maybe had 1.5 shrimp in it total. A $20 sandwich should be a bit more put together. The lobster roll was just ok. Again $36 for a roll in this town should be darn good. They need to improve the very minimal food options thy have to be AWESOME... really no excuse for that. Then they would be a 4-5 star place easy. I would definitely go back, but for the oysters alone.
author: Jody M.

description:
Solid choice for a seafood raw restaurant. Definitely heavier on the cold food options here. 

Oysters (4/5) - high end price but all class and delicious
Uni Toast (3/5) - didn't pick as much uni as brioche 
Louie Salad (4/5) - excellent rendition with nice varied greens. The sauce was a bit peppery but was a nice break from normal versions
Lobster roll (5/5) - it was pricey but probably the best lobster roll I've had. Not heavy on sauce and great on the chunks of meat. Fries were nice and the Dynamo dipping sauce was great

Service was fantastic. I wish they had bread served but can't have it all. All in all prices were on higher end but this place was worth it.
author: Victor W.

description: Came here for our 15 yr anniversary.  Found it on yelp while looking for a good oyster place.  Really nice place, service was great, and the oysters and the plates were amazing.  The lobster roll was perfect, couldn't get enough.  Would definitely come back.
author: Dany B.

description:
Food is around 3.5 stars, service is 4 stars, kitchen pacing is 1 star, and the space ambience is 2 stars. 

I am so ambivalent with this place. We got there at 5:30, they gave us a table right away and told us that they need it back by 7pm for a RSVP. No problem (1.5 hrs is plenty of time). We order (right away) oysters, crab cake, 2 soups, and mussels. It took 50 min (6:20) for 6 oysters to come out. Really? And the table is super tiny (18 inches by 18 inches) so they can only serve 1 thing at a time. This means we have gulp down all of our food, drinks, and pay for our bill in less than 40 min. 

The food is fine but nothing to write home about. You pay fidi price ($180 is our bill).

We would not return or recommend to any one with so many better options in the area.
author: Tracy L.

description: Went to Leo's around 5:30 on a Wednesday and it was super packed, so make sure to get a reservation. Really cute space with multiple rooms. Tropical theme is always a great idea. The front of the restaurant is definitely bustling, but the room we were in was dimly lit and quiet. The service was great! Had multiple servers who were always helping us with refills and our multiple orders of oysters. Food is a bit pricey, at $4 per oyster being the cheapest but it is really good. The dynamite sauce that went with the fries is so delicious!
author: Rebecca T.

description:
It's always a good sign when you can't decide what to order because you want to eat literally everything on the menu.

After much deliberation (and agreeing that we'd have to come back to try everything else), my friend and I settled on the following dishes:
- Kusshi, Peter's Point, and Fancy Oysters
- Sea Urchin Toast with Ginger, Soy and Scallion
- Salmon Tartare with Marrow, Capers and Dill
- King Crab Leo's Louie with Gem Lettuce, Mache, Radish, Fennel, Tobiko, and Sieved Egg
- Japanese Hamachi Crudo with Charred Avocado, Sea Salt and Scallions
- New England Lobster Roll
- Braised Short Rib
- Blood Orange Creamsicle Float

The oysters were super fresh. The Fancy Oysters are served with pickled tomato and horseradish, so be prepared for a little kick! The Hamachi was cut surprisingly thick and paired very well with the charred avocado.

Sea urchin is a huge weakness of mine. You could throw sea urchin on almost anything and I would love it. The sea urchin toast, while small, was very flavorful and light. If you're an uni fiend like me, the Lobster Roll and Braised Short Rib are also served with clarified uni butter.

Our entrees were excellent. I think Leo's Lobster Roll was the best lobster roll I've had in SF. I ordered the Braised Short Rib which was so tender it practically fell off the bone. The pureed potatoes were thick and creamy - such perfect texture! The dollop of uni butter was just the icing on the cake. ;)

If you have room for dessert, I highly recommend the Blood Orange Creamsicle Float. I'd love to try the Pineapple Sundae next time!
author: Kelly L.

description:
This restaurant had my attention before the doors even opened for biz and I was able to snag a reso opening week.

First impression: obsessed with the tropical decor and the lighting. Very warm and inviting. 

Sat at the bar to wait for the rest of my party and the bartender gave me a thorough run down of the cocktail menu and sold me on the Mah Jong. Stiff. Refreshing. Perfect. 

Leo's deviled egg: soooo good. I personally loved this one but my friends thought the sauce overpowered the flavor of the oyster. Maybe I just really loved the flavor of the sauce which was spicey and vinegary. My kind of sauce. 

House made tater tot: good but not amazing. But any menu item with tater tots must be ordered. 

Clam chowder: I'm from Boston so I have high standards for clam chowder but I thought this was so delicious. A must try!

Lobster roll: my fave lobster roll in SF is still woodhouse. 

Oysters: all fresh, all good. 

Would definitely try again but it's pretty pricey for the amount of food you get so be prepared to spend some dough!
author: Emily Y.

description:
This review is for the service only. I was dining with a friend at the bar and the bartender was initially nice, though obviously making comments about me and friend in Spanish. I am fluent, but I chose to ignore them and chalk it up to sexism and machismo, rather than let it ruin my night. 

I later mistakenly asked a server  a question and her reply, not only was completely unintelligent, never answered my question. Maybe all that bleach in her hair has seeped into her brain. She then proceeded to insult me in a back handed way and I chose to ignore the millennial attitude. Children are so rude sometimes. I watched her as she walked up to the bartender and started whispering in his ear and they both looked over. The bartender all of a sudden decides to start mixing and shaking cocktails right in front of us, banging the mixers as loudly as possible, as I sat there talking to my friend. I smiled at him and said "Wow, you're really working those cocktails." At this point we are done with our meal, but finishing our wine and I tell my friend was is transpiring, because she normally does not take note of these things. At this time the bartender comes back to make more cocktails in front of us and she says "Yeah, that splash was not accidental." and laughs. 

We enjoyed our meal and the time we had there, but the service really needs to be looked at. From reading others' reviews, this is not the only instance. I am a fan of all the Big Night Restaurant Group locations and even recently dined at Petite Marlowe, which was a completely different dining experience for the service alone. Leo's is unfortunately lacking in employees that will make their location a desirable place to dine at.
author: Norma ..

description: This place is A-OK as yelp says. I really wanted to love this place more but its definitely good. There is a large selection of oysters and some with unique toppings. The bar was also well stocked and had many good drink options. The lobster roll was good, for the price I wish it was a little different special. It was an ok option. All in all a decent meal.
author: Ian C.

description: This restaurant has a good vibe. Our server was amazing, helpful and really sweet. I felt the portions were small for the price but everything we had was delicious. We had the deviled egg w/buffalo fried oyster on top, 1 egg $6, pricy and very small but very good. I had several oysters on 1/2 shell, they were delicious and the vinegar sauce served with them was really good. We shared a bowl of the lobster/crab/shrimp bisque it was very rich, filling and really good. The lobster roll is really good!! Lots of lobster and very tasty. The seating was a little uncomfortable, we sat I. The 2nd room with a patio like chair with a pillow, hard to get comfortable in.
author: Kim W.

description:
This place is a complete ripoff. I think it caters towards people that can afford it and yet have mediocre taste in food. Pretty overrated. 

If you are coming here, do not get anything else on the menu except for the oysters and the cocktails. 

Outside of the oysters, I ordered the tuna dip and they literally brought out shredded tuna which looked like and tasted like Chicken of the Sea canned tuna. The Hamachi dish looked nice when it came out, but was not that flavorful at all. The bone marrow was sub par compared to other bone marrow I've had. Lastly, the crab cake is tiny. Taste wise it was pretty good, however it was pretty skimpy on the size.

Lastly, our server did not explain the menu to us at all and did not do a good job selling us on any of the dishes.
author: Alan H.
